I think homelessness is a huge issue. There are many different organizations that work to provide support but no one actually making significant change. We need an overarching solution. People don't become homeless overnight, and they won't get out of it overnight. We need to have a 2-pronged approach. 1st - before someone becomes homeless, we need to have a program that would allow them to access grant funding to catch them up and keep them from becoming homeless. It's far less expensive to catch someone up than to pay for all of the services they will need once they are homeless. 2nd - once someone becomes homeless, we need the ability to get them into mid - term (1-2 year) housing with wrap around services to ensure they can have their physical/mental health needs addressed, get or increase their employment, find childcare if necessary, and save money. During this time, they should also have access to financial literacy education, job training, and if needed, drug treatment programs. Waiting until someone has exhausted all options and is sleeping on the street before "helping them" by providing them 30 days in a motel, is only perpetuating the problem and keeping people in poverty.

Please consider the process of awarding a construction contract on state-funded projects. The current process of requesting a lump sum bid and then awarding to the lowest bidder has several problems and ultimately costs the state more money and time in the long run. The contracts team needs to create a database and flag contractors who have defaulted, been previously terminated from a project, or have a track record of poor performance. We have been awarding projects to the lowest bidder without being given an opportunity to determine whether that contractor deserves the right to work on a project. If we can establish a resource to the project managers and contracts team to vet through contractors, we should be able to disqualify a bidder due to poor performance, despite being the lowest bidder. The current process in place is actually costing the state more money and time to handle a poor-performing contractor. In addition, bids are requested as a lump sum. This is problematic for several reasons. Once we award a contract to the lowest bidder, we have no way of knowing if that bid actually includes all the requirements of the contract documents. As the process is currently set up, it is the responsibility of the contractor to ensure their bids cover the scope, however in several cases, the contractor ends up misinterpreting the scope and/or missing essential work. Better communication is key and can set up a project for success in the long run.

There are too many review steps in almost every government process. This usually happens because of errors in the process which lead to management wanting additional review to ensure there are less errors. When errors continue to happen, the review level continues to escalate. This results in leadership thinking their staff are unable to complete the task correctly and frustrating staff on the "moving target" or unclear expectations caused by various style preferences from different reviewers. This leads to requirements for staff to create additional documentation such as summaries, cover memos, and routing packets to navigate the higher management level reviewing the work. It is extra, non-value added work to explain what the work is why they are approving it. I recommend lowering the approval level to the lowest supervisory level who knows the program. This will reduce turn-around time for requests, improve customer satisfaction (since they get whatever service we provide sooner), increased confidence in employees, and better morale for teams. Additional levels of review do not eliminate errors, but instead increase them due to different standards between different levels of reviews. Instead, find out why the errors are happening and fix them at the source. This can be done easily between supervisors and front-line staff.

Two primary challenges I’ve noticed in my workplace are the lack of standardization and the amount of repetitive, manual work. Like others have mentioned, inadequate training resources, limited access to information, and redundant forms often slow down our ability to work efficiently. To address these issues, I’ve taken initiative by using Microsoft Office tools (SharePoint, Power Automate, Power Apps, etc.) that are already available to us at no additional cost to the state.  Here are some of the steps I’ve implemented:  1. SharePoint Site Development -Centralized and standardized all forms required for my role. -Used Power Automate to auto-fill redundant fields, reducing repetitive data entry. -Migrated resources from local drives to the cloud in compliance with IT policies, improving accessibility and collaboration.  2. Interactive Training Resources -Built a Wiki page to consolidate and standardize the training I’ve received from management. -Created step-by-step work instructions with embedded GIFs (instead of static screenshots) so employees can visually follow the process in real time.  By streamlining processes and digitizing resources, I’ve helped improve efficiency, reduce errors, and make information easier to access—all while keeping costs neutral for the state.
Additionally, many spaces are not ADA accessible. Upgrading spaces is costly and time consuming.

One of the challenges that needs further analysis is the replacement of staff when they move on from State Service. In most cases, departments are unable to fill vacancies until after the position becomes vacant. This leads to an exodus of knowledge and expertise from the department that is not easily replaced as it often takes years for an individual to become fully proficient in their role, establish connections with others and gain career long learning. While this practice may lead to salary savings, it creates a knowledge deficit which then leads to efficiency loss until such time as the individual staff person learns the position and becomes proficieint and beyond. If departments had the ability to hire replacement staff while the existing staff person was still present, the knowledge transfer would be more streamlined, and the institutional knowledge can be much more easily passed on to the new staff member. An in-between step might involve the creation of desk manuals for new staff to access however these will not necessarily impart the same level knowledge as the in person tutelage of the out-going staff member.

The contracting process is broken. Californians want government to have easy to use online tools, one-stop-shop permits, data access portals, and to use the latest technology to make people's lives better. Both IT and non-IT contracts are cumbersome and require navigating gate keepers who do not understand agency needs. If a project is deemed IT by contracting personnel, my agency will simply not move forward. If a contract gets flagged for the PAL process with CDT, the contract is dead, and we will never resubmit. Money lasts 3 years, and the PAL process can take that long, leaving no time for the money to be used on the intended project. Further, getting non-IT contracts through DGS is time-consuming and cumbersome with little added value, decreasing the time for the money to actually do work.   My suggestion would be to loosen up contract oversight on the frontend, actually provide training to staff, and provide more resources for auditing and enforcement of contract rules and ethics on the backend. In this way, SME staff will be trained on contract creation and execution (which is currently not the case) and can quickly get money out in flexible ways, taking advantage of as much of the 3 year money lifetime as possible, while knowing that they must strictly adhere to contract rules or their money will get pulled back and contracts will get cancelled. If you want staff to move fast, and use technology, this has to change.

California is in a housing crisis. To make California's government more effective in responding to this crisis, I suggest that State properties be reevaluated to see if entire properties or portions of properties would be suitable for housing conversion. For example, the agency I work for has a large open parking lot adjacent to its office building, all of which is State property and near public transit. Could we maximize the use of this open parking lot by moving the parking space underground and building medium to high density housing units on top? Could there be a public-private partnership so that the State continues to own the land but leases it to a private developer so that the State ensures its needs are met? I know some transit agencies are converting transit parking lots into housing developments. Akin to some school districts, could we dedicate a portion of new housing to State employees at a discounted rate to attract and retain State employees?

The Problem California’s current model for investigating and prosecuting insurance fraud is fragmented and inefficient. The Department of Insurance (DOI) houses the Fraud Division, a law enforcement unit operating within a regulatory agency. Simultaneously, $80.9 million in annual grant funding is distributed to county District Attorney’s (DA) Offices to prosecute fraud cases. This dual structure presents several challenges: Conflicting Missions: Regulatory agencies prioritize industry oversight and collaboration, which can conflict with the enforcement and prosecutorial roles of law enforcement. Operational Inefficiencies: DOI lacks the infrastructure, procurement agility, and legal support systems typical of dedicated law enforcement agencies. Jurisdictional Gaps: Only counties receiving grants can pursue fraud cases, leaving many areas underserved and creating geographic inequities. Short-Term Incentives: Grant-based funding encourages quick wins over long-term, complex investigations. Ethical Concerns: Financial incentives tied to prosecutions raise questions about the impartiality of justice. Recruitment and Retention Issues: DOI struggles to retain investigators, many of whom leave for better opportunities at the Department of Justice (DOJ). The Proposed Solution The proposal recommends transferring the DOI’s Fraud Division (163 peace officers and 75 support staff) and the $80.9 million in grant funding to the California Attorney General’s Office.

Forcing employees back into offices undermines efficiency, increases taxpayer costs for office space and reimbursements, and contradicts the state’s own climate goals.  The solution is simple: expand and normalize telework as the default option whenever the duties of a position can be performed remotely. This requires modernizing policies, investing in secure technology, and measuring performance based on outcomes instead of physical presence. Employees should be trusted to deliver results, and in my experience, productivity and responsiveness actually increase when telework is supported. By keeping more workers at home, California can cut emissions, save money, and provide faster, more effective services to residents. Telework is not just a perk. It is a strategy that addresses climate change, budget efficiency, and the quality of public service all at once.

This creates mismanagement, inconsistent access, and unnecessary strain on both interpreters and the people they serve. A practical, immediate step would be to require each state department that employs ASL Interpreters to have an ASL Interpreter Coordinator—a position held by a qualified interpreter. This model already exists in the State Schools, where interpreters are managed effectively by someone with lived professional expertise. Expanding that model across departments would ensure proper support, accountability, and better access for Deaf/Hard of Hearing employees and clients. Longer term, California could take a bold step by creating a Department of Language to house and organize all interpreters statewide—including ASL, Spanish, and other languages. This would centralize resources, guarantee professional management by people who understand the work, and ensure that language access is treated as an essential public service. Importantly, this would also allow interpreters to be shared across departments, so that if a DMV office (for example) suddenly needed an ASL Interpreter, the Department of Language could quickly dispatch one. This approach strengthens equity, efficiency, and accessibility across the state.

I understand that California has the Open Data Portal, but not all departments participate and that is to report deidentified data.  A solution to solve this problem could be to require all departments to participate in a shared data base, sharing information and working together to have the most up to date information.  Departments could also potentially share the cost of creating such a platform.  This could potentially eliminate some of the separate database changes taking place at other departments and modernize older systems.  This could also help HHS comply with some of the new CMS Final Rules by allowing cross reporting and by making sure each individual is only counted one time.  I would love to hear other solutions.

My team is fully crossed trained and have a back up (the back up has a back up too) for when they are on vacation or sick. When a member of the team has a planned outage they provide a list of pending items, what they are waiting on, and any contact information for the pending items to the whole team. The back up works the pending items as the necessary information is provided or updates are made. When the peer returns the back up provides a summary of what has been completed and what is outstanding.  The back up usually gets extra support for their peers to ensure nothing is missed. This is a win-win for everyone because the person that is out gets to enjoy their time off, work doesn't stop, deadlines aren't missed, when the person returns they are able to return without the stress of playing catch up, and the peers that are working know when they take time off they get the same benefits. This works when you set the expectation from the beginning and you take the time to cross train your team and if you have documented processes. Duties are rotated on a quarterly or semi-annual basis.

Public works and environmental projects often require multiple permits and notifications from different agencies—each with its own application process, timelines, and conditions. This fragmented system wastes time, creates conflicting requirements, and makes compliance tracking burdensome for project managers and contractors. I propose a statewide, centralized permitting portal where applicants submit one unified application describing project scope and location. The system would:  Automatically identify which permits and agencies are triggered.  Generate a single project ID to track progress across agencies.  Push project information to agencies in their required formats.  Host shared communications, map uploads, and condition tracking.  Consolidate agency conditions into one coordinated, conflict-checked permit package.  Enable online fee payment in a single transaction.  This platform would streamline environmental compliance, improve inter-agency coordination, reduce redundancy, and ensure consistent, transparent permitting for all public projects statewide.

California’s government must recommit to a centralized IT strategy—one that prioritizes shared services, specialized expertise, and fiscal responsibility. The current decentralized approach, where individual departments manage their own IT infrastructure, is inefficient, costly, and misaligned with the state’s legislative intent.  Many state agencies were created to fulfill specific missions—public health, transportation, education, and more. Yet today, these departments are investing significant time, energy, and capital into building and maintaining their own IT systems. This diverts focus from their core responsibilities and leads to duplication of effort, fragmented infrastructure, and inconsistent standards.  The California Department of Technology (CDT) was established to solve this problem. Assembly Bill 2408 and the resulting Government Code provisions laid the foundation for a centralized IT model—one that consolidates services, reduces redundancy, and enables departments to focus on their primary missions while leveraging CDT’s expertise.  Despite this mandate, many departments continue to operate isolated IT silos. This not only undermines the intent of AB 2408, but also wastes taxpayer dollars and slows statewide progress. The result: overlapping systems, inconsistent security protocols, and missed opportunities for innovation.

Before the pandemic, many administrative hearings were required to be in person. Since videoconference hearings became available, the vast majority of parties have chosen to utilize them. This allows individuals to take an hour or two off work instead of an entire day and avoid having to find childcare because they can participate from home. People save significant time by eliminating the need to drive or fly to a hearing, in addition to the carbon emissions from those trips. This change saves average Californians and small businesses hundreds, if not thousands, of dollars.  It also saves the state money. California agencies that pay for hearings no longer have to reimburse participants for the time and mileage spent traveling to hearings. If there is a default, those costs are completely wasted. Agencies that shift to remote offerings can make a substantial impact by reducing travel costs and minimizing waste, particularly important in our current fiscal climate.

In a nutshell, understand what is already in place creating new solutions. There is so much overlap between agencies that creates a great deal of duplication and confusion. Implementation is essential to success. Employees in the trenches too often are not identified as stakeholders, their expertise overlooked. I've been with the same department for 11 years, before that, I served in the military for 25 years. The primary problem I see has been the use (or lack of) technology.  There are so many things that would be more efficient if technology was utilized. We manage millions on excel spreadsheets, which I find unbelievable and a risk. When new technology is procured, the IT branch decides what to turn on or not and it's one thing at a time.  For example, we have two IT units, one oversees Outlook and allows us to use CoPilot, but the unit that oversees Teams, won't allow us to use CoPilot.  It makes no sense. The primary problem with state services is a lack of expense consciousness. Because government is structured to focus on a need being met, there is little interest in ensuring that the need being met is done in an efficient and cost effective manner. Agencies are punished for not spending all the money allocated to them because the next year, their budget gets reduced. This creates a use it or lose it mentality, and less concern is given on whether we are being good stewards of the public's money. To solve this problem, policies must be set that reward agencies that save the government money rather than penalizing them by reducing their future budget.   Another problem is that state agencies do not talk to each other.  We are all under the State umbrella, however, no collaboration or connection opportunities exist to be able to compare notes. Most agencies face similar problems and the ability to discuss possible solutions or even understanding what other agencies have done to address their problems is a missed opportunity.  There is no where that allows us to see the organization structure, duty statements, or reports completed by other agencies. There is no directory to reach out to other agencies and collaborate.  I would create a state agency directory and a policy would have require state agencies to comply by sharing their organization charts as well as contact information to other areas.  I would restrict access of executive leadership to only executive leadership.

Finally, I believe it’s time to fundamentally rethink how government employees work—and how government itself operates. The old blueprint no longer fits the realities we face today. We need to reduce redundant frameworks, streamline operations, and encourage departments to consolidate and collaborate across silos. Efficiency shouldn’t be a buzzword—it should be a mandate. But this isn’t just about internal reform. It’s about reimagining the physical footprint of government. Many office buildings now sit underused or entirely vacant. These spaces represent an opportunity—not a liability. By converting surplus government buildings into affordable housing, we can breathe new life into downtown economies that have long depended on a steady flow of government workers.This kind of transformation would not only address housing shortages but also diversify and strengthen urban centers. It’s a chance to shift from a government-centric downtown to a community-centric one—where people live, work, and thrive in more dynamic, inclusive environments.

let go of old tech that is no longer serving the community and actually use taxpayers money to use the current tech available instead of a large employee base in IT who are just not anywhere close to competing with the private sector.

Because of the high cost of housing around cities where most jobs and government offices are located, there is substantial inequality of opportunity for many Californians who cannot afford to live in metro centers. By shifting to remote offerings, such as the ability to participate in hearings and government decisions by videoconference, we can ensure that people who live in more distant (and often more affordable) areas are given equal opportunities to have their voices heard and contribute to shared goals.  Remote offerings further align with California’s climate goals, avoiding tons of CO₂ that would otherwise be generated as Californians waste time and money driving to formerly in-person meetings. Videoconference offerings also help us include Californians with disabilities who may struggle to join us in person due to challenges with transit and accessibility.   Since the COVID-19 pandemic, many state agencies have vastly enlarged the group of individuals who can participate through the change to remote and videoconference meetings and hearings. This conversion to a more accessible meeting style should be expanded so more people can benefit.

Moving forward it would be in the state's best interest to streamline the application/hiring process to the highest extent feasible to support having the highest amount of job applicants to hire from. This process would enable the state to hire and maintain the best available applicants available for potential hiring.

Help them to come out permanently and join mainstream. Those rules might curtail some of their freedom, but they should know that it's cost to pay for not being able to come out of homelessness by themselves. Problem: In many state departments, including my own, productivity is often hindered by rigid processes where documents must pass through multiple layers of review—sometimes six or more—before finalization. This not only delays critical deliverables but can render documents outdated or irrelevant by the time they are approved. Additionally, there is a noticeable gap in collaboration and communication between subject matter experts (SMEs) and executive leadership. This disconnect often leads to a reactive environment where teams are constantly putting out fires instead of proactively identifying and addressing potential issues. Solution: Introduce a tiered review system that empowers mid-level managers and SMEs to approve routine documents without requiring executive-level sign-off. This would reduce bottlenecks, increase accountability, and allow leadership to focus on strategic priorities. Implementing digital workflow tools with built-in version control and approval tracking can also enhance transparency and speed. Establish regular cross-functional strategy sessions between SMEs and executives to align on goals, anticipate challenges, and co-create solutions. This would shift the culture from reactive to proactive, encouraging innovation and long-term planning. Additionally, investing in leadership training that emphasizes trust in employee expertise and decision-making can help break down hierarchical barriers and build a more agile, responsive organization.

IT projects typically follow one of two methodologies -- waterfall or agile. Waterfall is great for smaller projects when one can reasonably estimate the scope, time, and resources needed to complete a project. Agile is better when two of those items are a little fuzzy because the project is large, but it's the only way to get the project to succeed. I have seen projects fail because state control agencies attempt to run projects one way while the department they are overseeing wants to do it the other way. First, CDT needs to have clearly defined approaches for both methodologies. Second, as part of the pre-work (e.g., FSR part), there needs to be an open discussion between CDT and the organization that is undertaking the project about which methodology should be used for the project to level-set expectations. Finally, as part of the FSR process, CDT should insist on receiving an entity-attribute diagram for the data that is passing through the system, so that they know that the IT team understands what it is that they are trying to build. All three of these points will reduce the risk of IT project failure.

What I have seen work best is moving beyond discussions and actually implementing ideas. Measurable results for state agencies require significant projects, supported by proper funding, a strong project team, and effective project management with government oversight to ensure deliverables are met.  In my department, I have participated in several such projects that enhanced both customer service and internal processes. For example, we improved how customers contact us, streamlined the way they receive information, and even developed tools that anticipate and provide needed information before customers realize they need it. These enhancements not only improved efficiency internally but also provided a better overall experience for Californians interacting with the department.  At a more practical level, I have also seen opportunities to improve efficiency by making better use of tools we already have, such as SharePoint, Excel, and OneNote. Often, staff lack training or examples of how to apply these tools effectively. Within my team, we began using SharePoint as a case management tool and OneNote as a shared notebook to store and share information. These small but tangible steps have helped streamline collaboration, improve knowledge sharing, and reduce inefficiencies in day-to-day work.

For improved state government efficiency, I’d suggest waiting until the AI hallucination rate decreases before implementing AI into state work. As an example, Microsoft Copilot has a hallucination rate of 27% and some specialized technical models have up to 60-80%. While policy requires double checking AI output, it is incredibly inefficient and embarrassing to have to retroactively correct published AI-generated hallucinations. I have used Copilot for non-work purposes, but these inaccuracies make me extremely hesitant to use it for my work, which involves data analysis and coding. Why should we as state workers trust AI output when there’s a proven record of hallucinations?

Overall, I think the state training program is woefully inadequate. The two-week new supervisor/manager training is a waste of time and doesn't cover most of what managers actually face. There are so many leadership development and coaching programs in the private sector that could benefit state employees, like Harvard Business Review or Stanford. Lareg companies often have leadership development tracks. VSP, for example, has two types of tracks you can enroll in -- one for those wanting to become executives and a second track for those who want to be subject matter expert leaders (but not necessarily an exec). They provide mentors, hold classes, and you feel encouraged that you're proactively growing professionally.  Employee management training, specifically, is reactive instead of proactive. I've worked closely with performance management units to discuss personnel issues and sent emails or disciplinary plans for their review. Rather than being trained ahead of time, before issues start, I'm stuck with escalating issues waiting for PMU to review emails and provide guidance. And then their guidance changes frequently depending on what they've recently experienced in court. It's immensely frustrating.

As a Californian and state employee, one idea I would add is the need for stronger accountability in leadership. Many employees see innovative, research-backed proposals—like expanding remote work, modernizing hiring, or streamlining processes—dismissed not because they lack merit, but because leadership defaults to outdated practices or prioritizes optics over efficiency. This discourages staff from raising ideas and reinforces a culture where “do as you’re told” outweighs evidence-based improvement.  I also believe the state should re-examine how closely it aligns with corporate pressures. For example, enforcing return-to-office mandates to mirror private sector demands undermines both efficiency and equity, especially when research and state audits clearly show that remote work saves millions in costs, improves productivity, and reduces emissions. It is difficult for employees to trust in California’s commitment to innovation when decisions conflict with the very data the state commissions.  From my perspective as a Californian, a government that models fairness, inclusion, and modern workplace practices builds greater public trust. Investing in remote-first policies, skills-based hiring, and leadership accountability would not only improve the employee experience but also deliver better outcomes for the people of California.

The Administration DEFINITELY needs to take a look at all the reports that DGS requires of departments.  Every month it seems like there's another report that's needed, that requires tons of research and data collection from staff and facilities all over the state.  What are they used for?  They are very labor-intensive, and it seems like a lot of these reports just pull and compile information DGS already has in their fleet and facility databases.  Some of these reports, like the sustainability roadmap, take SO much time.  It probably costs each department at least a couple staff worth of people just to handle DGS' reporting requirements, and these are resources that could otherwise be providing services to taxpayers and fee payers. DGS should make a list of all the reports they require, do an analysis of what each one is used for and whether or not there's even a benefit, see where some can be consolidated or can be taken over by DGS since they already have the data, and then free those resources up so departments can better serve the public instead.

Data suggests that there is a lot of taxpayer dollars that could be saved by fully embracing as much telework as possible, while simultaneously consolidating the amount of physical space and building leases the state takes up. Embracing telework in this way opens up state jobs to many more Californians all across the state rather than just people that live in a couple metro areas, it would reduce carbon emissions and traffic, as well as lower the cost of road maintenance in those areas, as well as be a huge benefit to the all employees. The FTB campus also has lightrail access, as well as a free parking lot, which would be a cost savings to employees who currently work downtown and have to pay for parking. the money saved from things like this could be used to help departments balance their budget and we would be able to better fund things that actually benefit residents of the state. The most prevalent issue that I have witnessed since becoming employed by the state is how poorly employees with disabilities are treated during the reasonable accommodation process. From my experience as an employee and union steward, it seems that disabled employees are treated like a burden during the reasonable accommodation process, especially if they are requesting telework. In most cases when the employee's doctor is recommending telework as a reasonable accommodation, departments will do anything to delay or deny telework as a reasonable accommodation. Departments have continually been allowed to ignore and violate the ADA, EEOC, and FEHA policies and regulations and oppose doctor's recommendations for appropriate reasonable accommodations.   As a whole, the state needs to hold departments accountable for following appropriate policies and regulations pertaining to reasonable accommodations. More timely processes and procedures should be implemented. It is unreasonable to allow each department's EEO unit/section 90 days to investigate themselves, while not providing an employee with a disability their recommended reasonable accommodations. A more consistent and streamlined approach needs to be developed to help support California's employees with disabilities to better provide them more equitable and inclusive work environment when working for the state.

Several problems really. But, the first is the integration of newer technology into the workplace. Each State agency has individual IT departments without a centralized, standardized model for operations. Yes, CDT exists, but they have limited control over which systems each agency uses. This minimizes their ability to provide statewide solutions to tech-based problems. It also means that each agency is essentially trying to solve their tech problems independently, sometimes without the necessary expertise to do so. This same idea applies to HR departments. Each HR department is under the guidance of CalHR, but often do things their own way. That lack of standardization causes issues in the short and long term, as policies and procedures are often more at the whim of senior leadership, without a larger strategy, and can even, at times, be in conflict with CalHR expectations. In both the CDT and CalHR cases, having these agencies be the owner of all IT and HR positions that are effectively deployed to other State agencies could resolve the lack of standardization across both critical functions. It ensures that every position receives the same base training for their respective fields, and even centralizes the hiring process for thousands of positions, freeing up other State agency partners to focus on their individual mission areas.

One of the simplest ways to immediately make government run more efficiently, is to institute full-time telework across state agencies. This would increase efficiency by enabling the ability of employees to get more done, decrease greenhouse gas emissions from personal vehicles, and save the state money by getting rid of excess office space.   Many state agencies also make the claim of wanting to increasing employee personal wellness, job/life balance, and spending more time with family. Full-time telework would solve these issues, and many similar ones as well.   It's time to move forward and embrace new ideas, and more efficient ways of doing things. This takes courage and leadership from the top, which has been in short supply these last few years. Full-time telework is an answer to more government efficiency at all levels, and California should act as the bellwether for all other States to follow on this issue.

A major problem in California’s state workforce is the inefficiency caused by outdated hiring and workplace policies. Rigid minimum qualifications and slow/ouutdated HR protocols block many talented candidates with modern skills from entering public service, which limits innovation and slows progress.  An even larger issue is the state’s approach to workplace flexibility. Despite state audits and extensive research showing that remote work increases productivity, saves the state millions in office space costs, reduces emissions, and improves work-life balance, some leaders continue to enforce return-to-office mandates. This is hypocritical for a government that speaks of innovation, equity, and efficiency while ignoring evidence that remote work achieves those goals more effectively than traditional office models.  To address these challenges: First, modernize hiring by replacing outdated minimum requirements with skills-based assessments and streamlined digital applications. Second, adopt remote-first policies that align with research and fiscal responsibility, prioritizing cost savings, efficiency, and fairness for workers. Third, strengthen protections against retaliation and ensure leadership training emphasizes equity, accountability, and inclusion.  By modernizing hiring and committing to evidence-based remote-first practices, California can move past outdated systems and demonstrate it is serious about equity, innovation, and effective public service.

One of the primary problems I see in California government is that our technical infrastructure is outdated and creates unnecessary barriers for both employees and the public. For example, many departments are still relying on PDF forms for timecards and approvals, which slows down processes, increases errors, and limits accessibility. To solve this, I would prioritize modernization of internal systems by moving toward cloud-based, user-friendly platforms that allow for real-time updates, digital signatures, and mobile access. This would save staff time, reduce administrative burden, and increase efficiency across departments. Another major issue is how state departments communicate with the public. Too often, forms, notices, and websites are written in dense, bureaucratic language that can be confusing. I would recommend shifting toward plain language communication across all state agencies, making information clear, simple, and accessible to all Californians. Alongside this, we should invest in practical resources like website tutorials, FAQs, or short instructional videos (e.g., YouTube walk-throughs) that guide people step-by-step in accessing services or filling out forms. Additionally, California has many departments that offer overlapping or complementary services—such as the Department of Rehabilitation (DOR) and the Department of Developmental Services (DDS), which often work with the same populations but in different ways. Stronger cross-department collaboration.

Every year we lose homes to wildfires and these losses are preventable. We need to mandate home hardening and defensible space including zone 0. There will be strong public outcry but often the hard thing and the right thing are the same. This will be costly and we need to provide funding for those who need it to accomplish this. This doesn't mean the $100k it may take to fully harden a home, but the low cost retrofits that are most impactful, on the order of $2-5k. Fuels reduction and prescribed fire are great and can have beneficial impacts to suppression efforts and ecosystem health, but if we need the money from somewhere it should be taken from there. Of course it's sad when the wildland burns, but if there is no loss of life or property most folks won't be too heartbroken. Work in the home ignition zone is what will have the biggest impact. We won't lose 0 homes, but the losses will be greatly reduced. This is a fixable problem, we just need the will to mandate it. There can be a timeline of multiple years to reach compliance if that will make it more palatable, but this needs to have teeth behind it.

The biggest problem I have encountered as a state employee has been the lack of accountability or actions taken for toxic management. I have now been in two units where this was a problem. In one there was a mass exit of employees who had been there for a long time (including myself), and in the other, they had extremely high turnover, most employees using return rights and not staying more than six months. Exit interviews should be conducted for every employee, no exceptions, and taken seriously, with actions being put in place to retain future employees. In the first scenario, losing the long-term staff put a massive workload on those of us who stayed, causing a decrease in moral and a loss of historical knowledge, which lead to more staff leaving. The management's poor behavior continued and because no changes were made, the work environment was extremely toxic. In the second scenario, the manager was an extreme micromanager who would single out and belittle staff, frequently teaming up with another manager to gang up on a single staff member. I know these scenarios are not unique, which is why I believe exit interviews for each and every exiting employee are essential, but only if they are taken seriously, good or bad.

Under the Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act (WIOA), every state has to set up not only a virtual labor exchange system, which in the case of California is CalJOBS, but under Title I, a One-Stop Center, which in California are the America's Job Center of California (AJCC). AJCCs provide many wonderful services to the public including connecting jobseekers and employers; case management on job-related services such as resume writing, job applications, interview preparation; on-the-job training and apprenticeships; secondary and post-secondary education attainment; veteran services; assistance to migrant seasonal farmworkers; and, much more. Unfortunately, whenever people ask me what I do for a living and I tell them about the services we provide, they are oftentimes shocked that all of these services even exist. When I tell them I work for the EDD, they automatically think I work for the Unemployment Insurance Branch or Disability Insurance Branch. The primary problem is that I don't think the state does enough to spread the word of our programs and the AJCCs and their purpose. The idea I have to solve this problem would be more advertisement whether that be pamphlets throughout state buildings or TV advertisements. I haven't really thought about the logistics or cost of all this. I just think that there needs to be more information given to the public.

Government should design public programs to help communities respond to the needs of their own community members, rather than government programs replacing the way individuals rely on community.  Therefore, every public program should rigorously evaluate the extent to which programs, and the public resources they administer, strengthen real connections between communities, families and individuals who are in need.  One area of policy this idea could be applied to is homelessness services.  Every homeless person has people who love them and want to help them, but there is often no safe way for family and friends to stay connected and engaged.  Government spending should always start from a place of prioritizing ways that it can strengthen/rebuild a vulnerable person's connectivity to their family and community. That could include creating pathways for a caring family member to make financial contributions to a family member struggling with mental illness or addition that are dedicated to housing, to food, to pro-social activities.  Or to create safe environments that are dedicated to helping people in a mental health crisis reconnect to people who love them.  People only heal in the context of community and belonging.  Our programs should prioritize paying for things that rebuild those actual connections.

This tool would act as a universal translator, allowing our diverse departmental systems, both legacy and new, to communicate and share common data automatically and securely, eliminating the need for redundant data entry. Problem: 80/20 rule with staffing. 20% do the majority of the work, 80% do bare minimum.   Solution: Radical, trailblazing idea to overhaul state service and incentivize employees at all levels. Throw out what you about state service entirely. Clean slate. Ready? Here is the concept: Departments have employment bands. Imagine layered cake - at the bottom is entry-level band, then above that is the supervisor band, the analyst band, manager and, chief band. That is it for positions. Each band incorporates all jobs for those positions. Every 8-12 weeks, staff can rotate to another job - let's call them "missions". To move up a band, you have to complete X number of missions and have led X number of missions successfully. Every employee must complete at least 2 missions annually. This kills silos, creates an innovative and growth mindset culture, creates competition, provides constant learning and gamification, etc. Each mission you complete you get a deliverable in hand to show the work you did with a score for your input. There is a list and those with the most missions and missions led, with good scores, are at the top, a constant changing leaderboard. This leaderboard is used to decide who moves up a level when there's an opening. Pay scales with tenure, not position, so you could decide not to move up a band. Folks would need to be focused, quick learners, with high accountability, excellent collaboration... tune in to my next post to see how we find these employees!

Implementing systems similar to those in the State Fund Special Investigation Unit (SIU) throughout the State in other agencies to spot fraud. Finally, looking for what areas we depend on the Federal Government and begin to reduce that dependency. Chart specifically where we receive the Federal Funding and begin to systematically self fund those areas. If we are not able to self fund look at reductions or creating alternative structures. As the 4th largest economy in the world we should be able to accomplish this task.   Lastly, we need to create a State Insurance model for homeowners, auto and business insurance. It's a required template used for all contracts and grants with CSUs and UCs. DGS should develop standard templates for contracts and solicitations that can be used by all departments. This would streamline the contracting process tremendously. It creates uniformity, and will increase the review and approval process by departments internal processes, as well as DGS' Procurement Division and Office of Legal Services. It would also impact the prospective contractors that are interested in bidding on our solicitations. If I build an RFP today, it likely looks drastically different from another department's RFP. The content may capture the same info - however, where the information might be found in the solicitation, and the formatting of the solicitation, would be drastically different from others. RFPs can be hundreds of pages, and can be overwhelming for contractors. A standardized contracting template, and a standardized solicitation template for things like RFPs and IFBs - would save the State time and money across the board. DGS, as the business manager for the state, should implement these templates in partnership with other teams.

As a Californian state employee with expertise in enterprise architecture, one primary problem I would address is the slow execution of projects due to repetitive and lengthy approval processes. A key improvement would be to implement a "Smart Approval Framework" that leverages a centralized repository of previously approved use cases. This system would use metadata tagging and AI-driven similarity analysis to identify when a new request closely matches a previously approved one. If a match is found, the system could auto-recommend fast-track approval, reducing redundant reviews.   This would not only accelerate execution but also promote consistency, reduce workload on review boards, and encourage reuse of proven solutions—ultimately driving more agile and responsive public service delivery.

To make workflows and services more effective, I start by mapping the current process to fully understand how it works today. This helps identify gaps, redundancies, and opportunities for improvement. Once those gaps are clear, I prioritize the areas that can have the greatest positive impact, and then design the future state around those priorities. For example, in leading the upcoming migration of the DHCS website from SharePoint to WordPress, I created a detailed journey map of the contributor workflow. This revealed where contributors were experiencing friction, such as redundant review steps and inconsistent remediation processes. By documenting these pain points, I was able to propose streamlined workflows, standardized training, and clearer content governance, improvements that will make the publishing process more efficient and the website more user-friendly.   Improved Version: Whoever is leading this effort should begin with discovery, connecting with department heads to understand their goals and priorities. From there, work together to build a shared vision for the future of California. Once that vision is established, you can integrate the issues and solutions identified from the ground up. This creates a two-way approach: bottom-up insights from staff and top-down alignment from leadership, which can then be captured in a cohesive diagram of the future state.
