As a state employee, I see one primary problem in the way new employees orientation is conducted. currently, NEO often requires multiple stae employees to physically present material, which uses valuable time and resources.  This approach could be modernized and made more efficient.  My idea is to fully diitize the onboarding process.  Core orienation content could be presented throug standardized, prerecorded modules that employees can watch, ensuring consistency across the state.  to keep it interactive, new employees should be able to submit questions digitally during the session.  a designated proctor could collect the questions and forward them to the appropriate department for follow up by way of email.  This solution would save both time and money.
More public transportation and affordable housing. I see some much new construction of housing in my area, but it is not really affordable.
I am a clerical employee and feel we are deeply underpaid for the amount of work we do in comparison to say a hearing officer who is paid far more.

California government spends money on things that do not improve our lives.  For example spending billions of dollars on a high speed rail line to no where and not adding traffic lanes to I 5 and US 99.  We are Californians and our cities are not designed for rail service.
Modernizing services to Cloud based, improving front end interfaces to make them more intuitive.

We are desperately under-staffed and it is difficult to keep people with institutional knowledge. Often the next promotional opportunity is in another district or another agency, which leads to loss of specialists. It takes a really long time to learn everything about a region, or just about how a particular agency works and which laws our particular work is governed by, and it slows everything down so much to lose that.

One of the biggest problems I've seen is centered around adoption of technology.  When FISCAL was rolled out statewide by the Department of Technology, the Department of Technology was among the last to adopt the program themselves.  The should have been among the first departments along with finance, to adopt the program, fix its flaws and learn it themselves before rolling it out every other agency.

One of the primary problems as a state employee is being subjected to the whims of ever-changing political climates. It often feels like state worker's voices are ignored by those who hold our future in their hands. Example: RTO to appease landlords despite evidence that it is a waste of time, space, and money. Solution: Listen to state workers, believe the data, stand behind your employees. I believe that California is consistently at the forefront of progress for many causes. It is what makes me proud to live here. We should focus on the big picture ahead of us. What do we want our world to look like? I would like to see a world that is fighting against climate change. A world that challenges the existing 40-hour work week status quo. I would like to see a world that utilizes technology to better the lives of human beings instead of increasing profits. How can California lead the way to that world? TELEWORK.

The state is pushing departments to contract with and purchase from small businesses and disabled veterans, which is great.  However, there should be a different set of requirements they need to comply with in order to do business with the state to make it worthwhile for them. We try to contract with SB/DVBE vendors but they don't want to do business with the state since it requires them to have a $1 million insurance policy.  That's a super expensive cost for them to do business, so how are we helping them by requiring this and telling them we're giving them an advantage?  If we want to help them out, DGS really needs to look at how that can be done. It's unfortunate that government gets in the way of them being successful when at the same time government is bragging about how much they're helping them.

Go Biz's Tracking Energy Development (TED) Task Force has been enormously successful at getting new electric generation resources on the grid in a timely manner. Their coordination across multiple state agencies is a best practice model.

One of the most difficult things about working for the State as a healthcare employee is having decisions made at headquarters in Sacramento that directly affect the lives of the people that I serve, often to their detriment, made by individuals who do not ever meet our clients or understand what they need. Decisions made by a top-down hierarchy often are made with administrators or managers in mind, and I think it should be the other way around. The primary role of a state worker is to serve the public, but often I feel that I am following regulations that are contradictory, don't make sense, or are needlessly burdensome at the expense of my clients for the sake of placating headquarters. I would want fewer top-down decisions; for leaders at headquarters to spend more time at the worksites they direct and oversee, to interact with the people who live there, and to pay closer attention to their needs and input; and more open communication from our leaders about what they are doing to address the concerns that we and our clients bring to them. Another piece that I think deserves a review is the State's policy of going with the lowest bidder for purchasing. Oftentimes, we get what we pay for, and products and services from the lowest bidders are also the lowest quality. There at least should be another metric we go by in addition to price, such as taking into consideration product reviews or how responsive a vendor is to customer needs.

I think policies and technologies need to keep up with the times. We are quick to adopt hot political topics and policies, but when it comes to implementing change that can benefit everyone, and likely even save money in the long run, we're not allowed to do it. There's a growing double standard on the needs of the state.

I have noticed many managers do not have a touchstone for what they do.  They do not have a structure for decision making and do not have a written process.  When a process changes, the information is dispersed word-of-mouth, take your own notes, no email.  It's like managers are chasing plausible deniability rather than efficiency and uniform process.  We have processes that make no sense AND what's worse, when a senior employee moves on there is nobody to explain a process - because it was made up of whole cloth or because it is genuine and correct but not written down.  I know there are other units that check our process to a point they never seem to notice these issues.

Problem: Public comment was received via telephone, mail, and email. This made it nearly impossible to fully review before the public meetings where decisions would be made.  Solution:  Implemented an online form to allow the public to submit public comment, and making it much easier and more efficient for our team to review public comment before moving forward.

Allow “regional” managers to approve purchases and services.  The multi step processes we currently must go through at the field level to conduct business all end up having to route through to several channels before we get a green light from top management.  Give managers at field level operation the tools and authority to ensure business can continue uninterrupted.

My program has procedures and desk manuals for every process. In all my years of service, I have never worked at another department that had desk/training manuals to help new hires. Manuals and procedures are updated regularly. Procedures are housed on our intranet, and desk manuals are in our shared drive. They also come in handy as reference materials when the SME is out of the office and their backup needs a refresher for completing a process.

I regularly see our Department turn to consultants to fill holes that should be part of our core competencies. This leads to cost increases, but even more troublingly it leads to a gradual loss of institutional capacity.

Please stop trying to change the world at the cost of being a Californian.  Our Smog laws and environmnetal Laws are not matched or adheired to by the rest of the Planet yet we continue to spend more and pass stricter laws upon Califonians to improve the world when the rest of the country is not participating.

Yes, require at least one meeting per month as a complete "team" (full unit meetings); I work in a unit here just the "leadership" meets to discuss the more significant issues. Analysts and other rank-and-file have gone a year without being included as a "team" in any substantive discussions that impacts operations. Many State departments consider AGPA's as important SMEs for these discussions. Not my Unit. There are the "leaders" and those with no voice-- hard to consider oneself a 'team member' when your job status has been exiled to silence.

training is great, but useless without accountability. I think often times people KNOW that what they're saying is inappropriate, but the current culture has embolded them to speak their deep dark thoughts as if they're acceptable.
I see examples of utilizing online resources instead of forms, mail, and appointments.

There is zero training for QRP's. Not even a 10-minute video.  We have huge case loads and come from different disciplines and yet no two offices do the same thing. Alignment and modernization is crucial for the success for DoR and aligned training is crucial.

The state faces many problems that telework could help alleviate. The state of CA can be a more attractive employer. We could lead in the space instead of trying follow the trends of the private sector. We have a completely different responsibility to the people we serve. Our "profits" are our efficiency and how well we manage our budgets and tax dollars.  We could lower cost, by reducing footprints. We can reduce environmental impacts by reducing commutes. Department should evaluate work and task that could be done via telework and in person.   With a concerted effort, managers can be prepared, trained, and supported. Expectations can be clear and departments can maintain flexibility.   In Person activities should encouraged, scheduled, and deliberate in with goals such as increasing collaboration/comradery. Trainings, in person-meetings, etc. should have the appropriate facilities available.   Finally, I think there should be more data available to make better decisions. Surveys for staff and managers to find gaps. Departmental specific dashboards etc.

I'll admit I'm no expert in organizational governance, but it has always struck me how fragmented CA's agencies/departments are. I think it's important to have decision-making independence for some kinds of agencies e.g., it might not be a good idea to have a Commission regulate itself, but does the staff need to be as separated as they are today? Maybe it should be easier to work on projects or tasks across agencies so good ideas can spread more quickly and agencies can have a better understanding of what their partners do and how they do it. This might be more true for the departments and agencies working on building things or managing natural resources.

Communication between supervisors and employees is a huge issue with every department I have worked in. There just does not seem to be ways to build as a team within when supervisor's don't take an active role in being personable and approachable to their employees.  Also, "suits & ties" at headquarters need to stop making decisions and changing policies when they haven't taken the time to get to know the issues and successes of the employees and supervisors. Administration should be focused on true employee wellness, not just making it look good for the public's eye. Part of that means being personable and truly transparent with staff members. Find out what they are really dealing with in their departments/fields.

Fragmented implementation, outdated solutions, and missed opportunities for system-wide transformation. Establish a technology procurement review board with cross-functional teams, cx strategists, and operational experts who evaluate not just on cost but scalability and integration, with user-centered outcomes. Existing systems are no longer effective.
I agree 100%!  Communication is key and we should strive to move forward as a team with no 'gate-keeping' of information.

I’d like to see the state make better use of the tools we already have access to at no extra cost. Since every employee has Microsoft Office tools available, we should focus on using these to improve our work instead of spending tax dollars on custom proprietary systems that could lock the state into expensive, long-term commitments.

One of the biggest issues I have seen in my service time is the fact that we are such a reactionary institution rather than a proactive institution.  It has been one of my longest and deepest frustrations from my time in rank-and-file to my time in management.  I would like to see us spend more time engaging with our employees from the top down and having thoughtful discussions on how some of these problems can be solved rather than allowing just the executives to make them.  I was an executive and having sat in that chair, I am well aware that we do not have all the answers.  It is the boots on the ground individuals that have so much to add to how we can be ahead of the game in some of these budget issues, RTW, and other critical issues we are dealing with.

The hiring process from the perspective of applicants can be quite complicated. Candidates often face numerous requirements when applying to state positions, which may discourage some qualified individuals. Removing the exam requirement could potentially attract more qualified candidates and streamline the process for all involved. This change could also lead to savings in time, resources, personnel, and finances over time.

Providing Better Customer Service: I supervise a team of 8 customer service representatives. I am part of Customer Service Center that is second to none at the State and Federal government level! This department has excellent track record for proving excellent customer service to Californians. I am constantly involved in daily continuous training meetings with my staff to better serve Californians.

We could also benefit from express buses that stop less frequently. Los Angeles has some of these and it was very efficient to travel across a main vein. Would love to see expansion of this in other cities in addition to rail.

Over the years I have identified two major inefficiencies in stat service: siloing and mismanagement. Siloing leads to duplication of effort across state government. When we conduct duplicative engagements with external audiences, it wastes their time and makes clear that we aren't coordinating internally the way we should. Collaboration and breaking down silos would lead us to be more efficient and make better use of expertise within and across agencies and departments.   Mismanagement is another very common problem I observe in state service. There are very few effective managers who support and empower staff to do their work effectively. Others are either totally checked out and non-responsive, or are some of the worst micromanagers I have ever encountered. So many times I see the state put forth goals for improving state service that ignore these issues. Hiring the right people won't matter if they don't get the support they need to do the work. Managers and supervisors need training to help them develop self-awareness, recognize signs of mismanagement in themselves, and grow to become supports rather than barriers for their staff.

Hiring - anyone who has already passed an exam and proven themselves eligible should not have to retake the exam/have their eligibility expire. Anyone who is already a state employee and qualifies based on years of experience for the next classification should also not have to take the exam to be put on the eligibility list, they should automatically be added. For example someone with 1 year as AGPA should automatically be on the eligible list for SSM1, someone with 1 year as SSM1 should automatically be on the eligible list for SSM2, and so on. It doesn't make sense to have to retake exams year after year for classifications you already qualify for.

I would like to see California reach out to a outside entity such as Texas and find out. How do they handle the unhoused situation and put it into action? We consistently throw good money after bad. And nothing is resolved.

Need a state-wide, electronic portal for reporting timesheets. Some departments are still submitting Excel spreadsheets filled in by hand, which is a very time-consuming process. People also have to learn new timesheet reporting processes when switching positions/departments - if it was standardized, this would be much simpler.

I think any sort of housing benefits would attract more people to be state workers. It could be a lower down payment percentage or something else. The generations nowadays are unable to afford housing, especially in California, and were sold the American dream that if you worked hard, you could afford a house. They're all disillusioned at this point and don't feel the need to work hard and contribute to society when the system isn't working for them.

Within California State Parks, there are ongoing issues with qualifications/hierarchy that creates ripple effects. The state has tried different ways to organize the hierarchy but what we really need is a park manager in charge of each park and the programmatic leads giving guidance for each programmatic area. What we have now are people doing multiple jobs to fill needs. Since that isn't recognized on their duty statement, they are not recognized on paper for it when applying for other positions. They also aren't recognized for it with any pay increase. This creates a very low morale and discourages people to stay within state parks, as they aren't recognized for the work they had to do to keep operations going. So many parks operate off of nonprofit partners, meaning ones without them are left with very few staff working far above their pay. It also creates a huge discrepancy in parks with areas with wealthy donors to nonprofits and parks in low-income areas.

Centralizing the state peace officer investigative positions into the AG or CHP would save Californian's money, allow for a greater variety of assignments, and be more consistent with models in other states.

I work for a very small department of a large State Agency with many different departments.  There is very little communication between the departments.  Improving communication could reduce duplication of effort.

I agree that a desk manual is needed.  A way to simplify the access and update to such a manual would be to provide an electronic version via Wiki or SharePoint site which can be modified/updated easily and made available to targeted audiences.

The core issue I want to address isn’t just about telework policies—it’s about a deeper, more entrenched problem within government culture: the tendency to default to “business as usual.” There’s a persistent inclination among leadership to repeat the same processes simply because they’re familiar and easy to enforce. This isn’t innovation—it’s inertia.  Take the push to return employees to the office four days a week. That’s a straightforward directive, but it sidesteps the harder, more meaningful challenge: making departments truly more efficient. It’s easier to mandate physical presence than to rethink workflows, modernize systems, or confront outdated bureaucratic habits.  The pandemic was a once-in-a-generation disruption that forced us to reevaluate how we work. It showed us that change is possible—and sometimes necessary. Yet instead of building on that momentum, many agencies are retreating to old norms. That’s not just a missed opportunity; it’s a failure to evolve.  The most urgent transformation we need isn’t logistical—it’s cultural. We must shift from a mindset of comfort and repetition to one of curiosity, accountability, and continuous improvement. Real progress begins when we stop asking, “How do we get back to normal?” and start asking, “How do we build something better?”

I have been a state employee for 20+ years and have seen many Bills passed without the resources and input by Program(s) required to implement the Bill included which causes ineffectiveness in implementation process and results in an increase in cost of staff time and cost to the regulated communities.  I had the privilege of providing input to the language in an Assembly bill in 2019 to the legislative team, which created a more robust Bill that Program was aware of and knew ahead of time how they could implement it in a more effective manner and outlined any resources that would be needed to do so.    To solve this problem I think that the authors of these Bills should do a exploritory process to get a better idea of the Program(s) their Bill would be effecting and have converstions with a Staff member(s) to have language the is clear and implementable, which makes it easier when the Bill is passed for Staff to implement.

Improper leadership is the biggest hurdle.   Often those who are selected to lead us are unqualified, hold old and rigid mentalities, are afraid of change and won't even entertain possibilities, are mediocre at best.

With the return-to-work order at a time when EVERY freeway going into and out of Sacramento is under major construction causing an increase in congestion, Teleworking and/or staggered work hours could help reduce the environmental impact, improve safety, and can greatly reduce the stress of commuting.  Public transportation is not always an option in outlying areas. Teleworking has proven to have a increase in efficiency and sharing workspaces can save money on overhead costs.  In addition, the increased costs of commuting will prevent most household budgets to frequent local businesses surrounding work locations.

In a decentralized department, stronger program management and tracking systems, greater process standardization, and more comprehensive leadership training (beyond online courses or webinars) would add significant value. Reducing the expectation for employees to be ‘jack of all trades’ would also help ensure that backlog work is addressed more effectively and that staff can focus on their core responsibilities.

Return to office has been a massive waste in taxpayer dollars and employee time, even the two day a week mandate. We should not be attempting to prop up downtown businesses and real estate portfolios of people who donate large amounts to political campaigns on the backs of the taxpayers and state employees.   As a state that prides itself in technological innovation and leading the way to fight climate change we should be mandating telework as much as possible. The rule should be if you don't need to physically do something in the office (open mail, hand sign/deliver documents) you should be working from home.

System software is often very outdated and we either can't access or can't *afford* to access updated software that will allow us to work more efficiently. Processes often seem cumbersome and disjointed. An example of this is submitting a travel reimbursement claim through CalATERS. I can only create part of my claim in the outdated Java program, but then have to email or mail all of my receipts and documentation. We are also in desperate need of access to quality project management software (such as Monday or Asana). There are many more examples. The outdated software we are required to use slows our work flows and wastes valuable staff time.

Leadership: The executive leadership team does not have the best interests of the department in mind.  Nothing kills a team faster than a leader who doesn’t trust them.  Leaders—your people aren’t there to make you look good. You’re there to make them successful. Without them, you don’t have impact. You have a title. Lead with trust. The results will take care of themselves.  There is misalignment, miscommunication, trust, and a continued need to break down the silos. Also, for women in leadership: women should be lifting up and celebrating the successes of others. There is a lot to be gained from learning from others.  Lastly, leaders, managers, supervisors: do not elevate yourself on the backs of others.
Right? Thanks to term limits, corporate lobbyists have stronger subject matter expertise than the legislators.

I would love there to be free trainings available on how to use Microsoft power bi. It's such a powerful tool but does have a learning curve. I think data dashboards are really helpful for making data driven decisions.

Modernize the civil service hiring process to be more equitable, including an examination of underpaid and unprotected non-civil service seasonal and part-time help. Address the strict, rigorous, confusing, selective, lengthy, maze of procedures that leads to possible civil service employment.

Direct supervisors who know their staff's capacities and trust them to carry out their duties has been the most effective dynamic I have witnessed as a state employee. While it does depend on hiring the right person with the needed skills, knowledge, and abilities, no process or method will be effective if employees aren't empowered to carry out their duties independently and with necessary accountability.

This is specific to the California Model of incarceration.  The California Model is not about money and it is not about modifications.  The California Model is about mindset! Change the mindset of the leaders and, through the principle of Extreme Ownership, we can collectively change the mindset of the staff and the incarcerated.  At this time, insufficient effort has been made to change the mindset of the policy makers and stakeholders at the top, so, as a result, we will never success on the front lines.
I feel the organization I work is so "top" heavy, which creates siloed departments within the organization and constant miscommunication and confusion.

Return office policy should be adapted to allow full-time telework for classification or roles that are not required to be in the office. This would expand the ability to recruit statewide, allowing for an improved competitive hiring process.
Antiquated procedures like time keeping/payroll which still use various systems across Departments, ranging from Excell spreadsheets to external systems.

Telework. I had a job officer that paid significantly more and was located closer to where I live when my current position was offered to me. I chose my current position because of the remote option. Telework offers the flexibility many employees desire. It also draws a larger and better pool of talent.
Using a database that is accessible statewide and to the public.

Grants - If I was running a business that $100,000,000,000.00 in debt, the last action I would take is to just give out free monies. Our Grant programs are horribly wasteful and inefficient where 50% of the funding often goes towards administration.
Greater work-life balance being taken into account can help motivate employees to work harder and achieve more. A revisit to the RTO mandate might be in order.

We need to improve iir K-12 public schools. Educators should be laid more. Schools should be fully supplied with everything they need to twach our kids. Parents and teachers should not have to go out of pocket to pay for school supplies.
I would love to see better wages for the cost of living that increases every year.

Doing the tasks with sincere efforts and going above and beyond the scripted job duties. I also see the hiring process is not conducive to picking the smartest people for the posted jobs. It is more artificial than a genuine selection of the candidates.

Training and transparency. As new employees to the state we do not know why, what, or where. If staff were told what we are doing, why we are doing it, how it affects others jobs, where each department is and the roles that each one has, it would bring a clear understanding of our job and how best to interact with each department

I have written procedures for various work queues in my department, eliminating the unnecessary steps and excessive language. Proper guidance provides better customer service through effecient work practices.

I have worked for the state for 15 years, and I love my job.  However, the most challenging part of my career was in my previous position.  The red tape was a nightmare.  Our team would propose ideas to improve patient care and/or provide education to staff, but we faced so much resistance that most people eventually stopped trying.  The culture in my last position within the state was the main reason I decided to transfer to my new role, which is a complete contrate to my previous experience.

I find that managers are frequently covering for their lack of knowledge and have no idea of where to get resources or are afraid to be found out.  They effectively need clergy or a "safe space" that can share actual process and facts to them without fear of being found out.  When people do not understand words, they can't simply be removed from instructions and carryon - this is happening and affects citizens.

In order to make things more effective with my consumers I provide better services by active listening, positive communication, focusing on the problem and finding solutions by maintaining a positive attitude.
I think the largest problem is keeping up with work orders and maintaining the highway. We have more requests than we are able to handle.

I work in one of the many Legal departments. I receive in service of process. When someone sues the department and its employees, it is codified in law that each person/department gets a copy of the document.  Just last week, I had an individual name/sue 30 different people. So per law, each one needed a copy of the over 500 page document.  We need to change the law so that we can take electronic service. That way instead of piles and piles of paper (where I scan in only one copy) and distribution happens electronically. What a waste of paper and human effort. I have heard the law needs to be changed. Okay, let's change it! This effects every legal department in the state and also anyone else who serves papers on anyone in any law suit.

The state spends millions of dollars a year on office space throughout the state. Allowing and promoting telework throughout state service will allow for that money to be freed up and spent on more pressing issues that affect all of California like homelessness, housing affordability, and lack of affordable healthcare.

Living in CA is expensive! I truly believe if you can work fully remote, let your staff do so to save money and manage their work/life balance. I have great staff who get more done than when they go into the office. If going into the office is truly for morale purposes, have it be one day a month where the entire building comes in to have everyone meet and do a team building event and not necessarily work. Then have an outing to do events in the community or eat out to support businesses.

Full time telework for all state workers. If any agency or department wishes to deny telework, it should be supported by verifiable data. If there is a legitimate need to report in office, the reasons should be specific to the state worker and their department, division, branch, unit, etc.

We need to implement solutions to minimize transportation costs and burdens. This includes continuing to offer telework, reducing parking rates and preventing spikes, accounting for parking at new government buildings, offering more public transportation opportunities, allowing for flexible work schedules, and maintaining and expanding our transportation infrastructure.
How can you take care of a child and do a full-time job? Particularly if they are under 5-7 years old?

It would be good if the GO considered the Leadership skills of appointees prior to appointing them. Or having a training program for them to complete on leadership. I've encountered several directors over the years that literally hide from staff because they don't know how to lead and answer tough questions. They don't have firm opinions or leadership skills to engage with their teams. They see themselves as 'too important' to mingle or engage with the line staff. You cannot lead of they do not follow... we need to add a degree of inspirational leadership to the qualities of our appointees.
1. Communication with lower staff. 2. Streamline process to cut out unnecessary review.  3. Empower lower staff to make decisions.

I would like to standardize templates and basic duties across agencies and departments.  Having to relearn the job that you were already doing elsewhere because the culture is different is inefficient.  Provide a standard writing style guide for Contracts and Procurements across the state.   Invest in a statewide procurement solution that all departments have access to. A way to track work, control who edits, and route for approvals. Maybe even tie it into the signature processes.  Something that would work for an analyst working in a small shop under 10 people as well as the large departments of thousands.   Ensure consistent and appropriate levels of training. This promotes the transferability of skills and ensures a baseline for promotions.  Provide information on how analysts can successfully promote through the ranks. Workforce development stops with Executive Assistants, Secretaries and Office Technicians. Analysts and other employees would like assistance and a clear, step by step process for how to promote within the state.  Offering Interviewing training as a part of the career growth.   Offer advanced analyst positions above AGPA or Research Analyst that does not require moving into management. Often people are subject matter experts, but that does not always transfer into leadership capabilities.
I am excited by the amount of departments who want to start using plain language. It's so important that we write clearly and without jargon.
Utilize shared spaces (e.g. Teams, WhatsApp, Slack) to communicate and collaborate with others.

A mentor program for first year or new employees who come into state service. Learning how the state functions, how long it takes for certain tasks or forms to be implemented can be daunting and confusing. Having a mentor or buddy to walk new employees on what to expect would be a great way to increase turn over and have employees engage with each other in meaningful ways.

I was responsible for the successful replacement and decomission of my department's main legacy application which collects near 200 billion dollars annually. This system was reaching end of life with no support so had to be replaced. As the project director, I planned, managed, executed and successfully deployed a Cloud solution to replace the againg applications. In doing so, I also identified new source of revenue which has been saving taxpayer $100,000,000 annually.

Where does the individual take responsibility? The government is not responsible for success, just equitable access to the opportunity. Education is of the utmost importance, parent involvement is paramount, job opportunities need to exist, and a realistic examination of the skills an individual has to offer the market can't be overlooked. Give a man a fish, or teach them how to fish... a lot of people don't like fishing.

Yes, the work that I can do from home compared to working in the office has only become for efficient reducing paper, reducing storage of records and becoming more streamlined.  increased Our management trust in and believed in telework and it has only helped us, from having a better candidate pool to choose from when hiring, to retaining our employees, to reducing the cost of rent, to reducing commute traffic, sparing the air
Prepared my own training for my new staff. Created samples to share with auditors, so they are not spinning their wheels on how a workpaper is supposed to look like.

As a 3rd generation Native Californian and a proud State of California Employee I love this state. It has everything one needs. Rich culture, beautiful scenery, beaches, mountains, deserts, farmland and numerous other rich natural resources. We are truly one of the most unique geographic regions on the planet. But all  State citizens pay dearly for the privilege to live here. Creating a more efficient government (cheaper but effective) and reducing the significant tax burden we all face would be a very welcome change.

Yes, but - I've seen where the SME jumps to the contractors because of the better pay, then the backfills don't actually know how to do the job, so they have to hire the contractor to get access to the SME.

I see this as well. Many old school management styles or dynamics can happen when we have this kind of mindset. We are adults managing other adults. We should avoid any kind of parent-child dynamic, which seems to be a more old school way to manage.

One problem I've observed is cultural. I think many people say something is "not their problem" and so we end up in a tragedy of the commons situation, where nothing is anyone's problem. In truth, I think each team needs to exercise greater ownership over the problems we can all see. Furthermore, I think people need to be willing to accept more responsibility when systems go down or when problems occur.
The staff I support have minimal resources, so i make every effort to provide as much as I can.

The telework audit showed that $225 million could be saved at the current two day in office schedule. If we were full telework, we could probably save even more. As a unit wildlife biologist working in the Bay Delta Region's Wildlife and Lands Management Program, one of the biggest problem areas I see comes down to a lack of staff, training, and resources to be able to effectively address the public's needs surrounding human-wildlife conflict education and response. For example, we typically have one biologist assigned to cover 2-3 counties in the Bay Area. That single biologist is responsible for managing thousands of acres of CDFW lands, responding to human-wildlife conflict incidents in the counties they cover, AND monitoring/studying various taxa of wildlife, whether it be threatened and endangered species on our lands or game species. The vast majority of the time, we receive calls from the public about injured wildlife or smaller wildlife that are stuck in netting or fences, etc., and we do not have the level of staff or resources to address such calls. Which leaves the public asking: "If animal services won't address this and you guys can't address it, then who will?" To which the answer is, sadly: nobody. We used to have temporarily funded conflict wildlife staff who could help address such calls - and we do not have them anymore - and our wildlife and public affected by such wildlife suffer the consequences - and it doesn't make the Department look good when we aren't able to address such calls on a more regular basis.  We also need to have a much better presence on social media and spend more time educating the public

We accelerated the digitization of our processes, shifting away from paper-heavy workflows and outdated systems. This wasn’t just about convenience; it was about survival. By streamlining operations and cutting through layers of bureaucracy, we empowered teams to do their jobs more effectively and with greater autonomy.  We also introduced flexibility for employees—something that had long been resisted. Remote work options, flexible schedules, and trust in individual accountability led to a noticeable boost in morale. People felt seen, respected, and more engaged.  Perhaps most importantly, we reimagined how we communicate within the department. Barriers broke down, silos dissolved, and collaboration became more fluid. These weren’t temporary fixes—they were foundational changes that made us stronger, more responsive, and more human. But unfortunately, all this under threat with mindset of we have go back to office and return of the old way of doing things mindset

As a seasoned CA employee, I see waste/fraud in the use of licensed BU 9 classifications. I would recommend an audit of all BU 9 duty statements to determine if a license is actually required to do the job.   I say this because I have seen the state increase the use of "licensed" BU 9 staff when a license is not necessary to complete the work. DGS' Division of the State Architect, the Building Standards Commission, and the Office of Sustainability, as well as CalTrans previously hired non-licensed employees to complete the work that does not require a license.   However, in the past decade these Departments/Divisions/Commissions have stopped using classifications that do require a license. The problem is that the work required by these entities can be completed by a combination of licensed and unlicensed staff, but by hiring only licensed staff, the state is wasting hundreds-of millions of dollars.   A licensed architect/engineer gets paid (after benefits) $250k/year or more. An unlicensed person doing the work that doesn't require a license gets paid $150k/year. Multiply that $100k/year savings by the thousands of staff at DGS and CalTrans that are paid for their license but don't perform license-level work.  By hiring unlicensed staff to do the unlicensed work, there is also an opportunity for the state to recruit and maintain staff.   But STOP paying licensed BU 9 staff to do work that non-licensed staff can do. It will save the state at least 1/2 a billion dollars.

It makes it better for Californians, but also for those processing the paperwork. When people understand, the whole process goes smoother, even if the reason you have to fill out the form is frustrating. This doesn't mean dumbing things down, but thinking about them deeply to make sure we convey exactly what we need and removing any excess fluff. This takes a lot of thought, because it requires us to question why we are doing something, why we are asking other people to do things, and whether the current process really gets us there, in practice and not just in theory. It takes more work upfront, and can take some convincing, but it's really just applying a "measure twice, cut once" mentality to work. I've seen staff workload get lighter as a result, freeing them to do more in other areas (especially ones they're interested in). I work with a historically difficult demographic and I've seen these methods systematically repair our relationship with this population, making our work easier, but also allowing us to build on those improvements. Improving processes and providing better customer service, when done mindfully is a circle.

Bias Elimination Through Automation:  RAG (Retrieval Augmented Generator) systems make decisions based on explicit criteria, not writing quality. This is a LLM (Large Language Model) utilizing only documents that have been curated. Consistent application of standards regardless of reviewer mood or workload Transparent decision logic that can be audited and explained  Cost Reduction Through Intelligence:  80%+ of applications would never need a review by a human, dramatically reducing staff costs Human reviewers focus only on genuine edge cases requiring judgment Real-time feedback eliminates multiple submission cycles  Outcome Focus:  The system learns from actual grant performance, not just compliance Evidence-based interventions get prioritized automatically Continuous improvement based on what actually works for students, data would drive decisions.  Practical Implementation Notes:  Start Small: Begin with one grant program (maybe Perkins V) to prove concept and refine algorithms Data Integration First: The auto-population from existing systems is crucial - RAG works best when it has complete, accurate data Change Management: Frame this as "freeing staff to focus on helping districts succeed" rather than "replacing human judgment" Transparency: Make the AI decision logic completely visible to districts - they should understand exactly why they were approved/denied

I work for the California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation (CDCR).  One of the largest financial burdens of this department is the amount of movement made for inmates (i.e. transfers from one prison to a different prison).  Specifically, when an inmate's mental health level of care is changed to a "higher" level of care (i.e. to EOP, ICF, Acute, MHCB), the inmate is transferred "short-term" to a different prison.  This transfer takes multiple Correctional Officers driving across the state to take the inmate from Point A to Point B.  As the Mental Health level of care is temporary, they are transferred back (or to a new prison) within a short period of time.  The same inmates are transferred many times throughout the year, whenever their Mental Health changes.   In my opinion, it would be cheaper, more cost effective, and more efficient, if each prison had the appropriate staff at that prison to treat that inmate's mental health level of care. So... don't transfer the inmate from Point A to Point B multiple times; keep the inmate at Point A, and have on-site staff treat the inmate.    This would be a huge cost savings.

There are many ways in which we can boost morale that need to be taken into consideration. Employees should not be paying to park to work. From a hiring and recruitment standpoint, I believe the state should explore implementing relocation stipends and location-based incentives in areas where compensation does not align with local housing costs.  For example, the Communications Operator classification in Siskiyou County currently offers the same pay as in San Diego County, despite the significant difference in cost of living — with housing costs in San Diego nearly triple those in Siskiyou. This imbalance contributes to low tenure and retention within the classification, especially in higher-cost regions.  If the state were to establish automatic stipends or geographic pay adjustments, similar to those used by the federal government and based on GSA locality rates, it could make these positions more competitive and appealing to prospective candidates. This approach would support workforce stability, improve retention, and help ensure statewide operational readiness across all regions.

Our Governor has made important strides, but he is missing the mark on one key issue. If California truly wants to reduce its carbon footprint, the solution isn’t to force everyone into electric cars, it’s to reduce the need for cars and commuting altogether. REMOTE WORK is the future. It cuts emissions, lowers costs, and allows employees to be more productive while leaving face-to-face gatherings for when they matter most, social and collaborative purposes. The Governor’s RTO order ignores both technology and the cost-saving benefits that remote work provides. It especially harms employees with disabilities who cannot safely or reasonably commute, even though they have already proven they can perform their jobs effectively from home. California should lead by example and show that sustainability starts with the state workforce, by embracing remote work, not resisting it.

This is a big question!  A problem I would like to address is that bans on harmful practices, products or substances often are passed with enforcement beginning years later.  These delays often seem too long to me, and when it comes to practices / products / substances that harm the environment and / or public health, to prioritize the need of industry to transition slowly is to de-prioritize public health and the environment.  Things that are harmful, like dragnet fishing, or PFAS in dental floss, to give actual examples, should be banned as soon as possible, rather than as soon as is profitable.  If it were up to me, I would have banned dragnet fishing immediately and PFAS in dental floss within 6 months.  Both were passed with several years for implementation.

State employees who drive a state vehicle for their jobs, such as inspectors, investigators, etc, have an assigned WEX Fuel Card to purchase gas while on the road.  With the transition to ZEVs, why can't these WEX cards be used at EV charging stations?  Especially Tesla?  Departments must either have a separate credit card number to provide employees on their Tesla app, which then subjects the card to misuse and unauthorized non-state purchases, or employees must use their own personal credit cards and then submit a travel expenditure claim to request reimbursement.  If a WEX card could be used to charge an EV, it would be so much easier for state staff and less work for accounting staff to manage multiple cards, process travel claims, and management to review and approve so many different payment mechanisms.  If the WEX card could also be expanded to be used for small repairs and oil changes, staff wouldn't need to spend so much time finding a repair shop that will accept state payment policies, and can also get repairs done much faster without downtime.
Seeing our public officials in public outdoor spaces would be great to see. "Connecting the face to the place."

Full time telework solves so many problems.  Many private leases can be cancelled to save millions for the State.  For staff that still must come into the office for a legitimate in person requirement (processing mail, etc), multiple departments can consolidate into existing State owned buildings.  The Franchise Tax Board campus would be a great place to consolidate these staff.  There are multiple buildings to house different departments with free parking.  Staff that get to telework 100% would be much happier and more productive at work and at home.  It was proven to work during the pandemic.  There was never a problem with full time telework and it didn't need to go away.  Staff in positions that can't telework would have something to strive for in future positions.  The State government would be able to obtain the best talent away from the private sector and offer a new incentive to work for the government.  Taxpayers would be happy to see the cost savings.  I suppose the only people unhappy with full time telework would be urban business owners.  It is said that urban areas hurt when people telework.  But there are winners and losers in everything in life.  For every downtown business owner that is unhappy, there is a business owner in the suburbs that is getting more business.  Let people live and work where they want to.  Less commuting is less polution and traffic, which also benefits everyone.

As a former Federal Employee, and current state employee, I think there is a gap when it comes to holding employees and leadership accountable to their responsibilities. To solve this problem, I think we should ensure that employees and supervisors are being periodically checked in on. I also think supervisors should undergo a 720 degree review - where they are appraised by their supervisors, employees, and themselves.

The streambed alteration permitting program (EPIMS) is extremely difficult for the layperson to navigate and complete successfully. We receive requests for assistance daily, which distracts Environmental Scientist staff from other priorities. The helpdesk is understaffed, and the phone contact is no longer operational. Aside from scrapping the current program altogether for new in-house designed software (should be a top priority), a virtual in-program assistant would exponentially improve the end user experience, and scientific staff would receive far fewer assistance requests.

One issue that deserves more attention is the disconnect between state employee compensation and the rising cost of living across many regions in California.  While I understand that salaries can improve over time through merit-based increases in line with the classifications pay scale, the reality is that many state positions, some of which require degrees and several years of relevant experience, start out with compensation that is classified as low income under both state and federal income limits in numerous counties. These are not entry level roles, yet the starting pay often does not reflect the level of responsibility, expertise, or the cost of living in the areas we serve.  Public service is deeply meaningful and essential work. Most of us do not enter this field with the expectation of becoming rich. However, when experienced professionals are struggling to meet basic living expenses, it creates an external burden that can impact their ability to perform at their highest potential. Financial stress can affect focus, morale, and long-term retention, ultimately impacting the quality of service we provide to the public.  Addressing this issue would not only support the well-being of dedicated employees but also strengthen the effectiveness and sustainability of our workforce. Investing in fair and competitive compensation is an investment in the quality and continuity of public service.

Virtual training gave a great resolve for COVID, I feel like the classrooms need to come back now.  People learn differently, but as a manager, I noticed that more of my new hires come out of their virtual training confused and unclear about the topics that were covered.  Some really don't appreciate the electronic platform because it's impersonal and doesn't allow them to feel engaged in the lesson.  I also find that the electronic platforms do not offer the opportunity for networking, which is so valuable as you move on in your career.  I also find a lot of these trainings are being cut too short.  My employees don't feel like they are being given the opportunity to really retain the information, which only sets them up for failure.  I am a "hands-on" learner myself, and so when my new hires tell me that they would have liked to physically handle some of the example processes, instead of virtually working through them, I can completely empathize with that.  New hires are going out into their offices and causing even more exhaustion and congestion amongst those that already know the job and are trying to slow down enough to help the new hires catch up.  I find that there is much more "on-the-job" training needed, but we are already so stressed for workers that this causes a major inconvenience for the office to have to pick up the slack where the training is lacking.   Conclusion: Bring back classrooms for "beginner" classes and elect dedicated mentors for new hires.

Ther needs to be emergency spending exemptions that remove the bureaucracy and allow the agencies that are responsible for emergency spending to get it done immediately. Emergency is the key word. As a manager, I try and involve my staff as much as possible and solicit their feedback before making decisions on particular course of action that will directly affect them and their workload. I work at a smaller department and my team oversees a wide array of administrative functions, and I frequently try and remind myself that I am not always going to be the subject matter expert who has the answers to every question that comes up. As a state employee I've realized that there really is no precedent in place that dictates how we shall do our job. There are only OP's that show and ends to a mean but doesn't show how to get there. It is up to the managers and past employees (if you're fortunate enough to be enlightened by their strategies) to aide us on how to complete our job in the most efficient manner. To that I'd like to state that when an employee promotes, transfers, or leaves CDCR completely, there is no overlapping of employment of the predecessor and successor for training. When an employee assumes a position for the first time, that employee must learn to govern themselves. They must teach themselves to be efficient and make the most out of their time. With that said, I think all employees have had to invent ways or utilize methods to ensure efficiency, whether self-taught or passed down from their predecessor- nothing is put in place to give employees direction on best practices to ensure work is completed in a tried-and-true efficient manner. There is nothing for employees to utilize and build on to tailor it for their institution specific duties. Employees are overall responsible for how their day is managed and it can highlight ones' drive to do well or not and can increase turnover rates.

Outdated minimum qualifications and lack of ability to promote in place which leads to a lack of expertise in state positions.  For lack of expertise in state positions, low paying and low qualification positions see high turnover. In administrative units we lose someone with years of knowledge and experience so that they can promote. That person is worth more in their current position with the knowledge they have amassed. If they are eligible to apply to a higher administrative position, they should be eligible to promote in place. The high turnover makes state processes extremely slow as we wait for someone to be trained or wait for the position to be filled.   For outdated minimum qualifications, an example is the Water Resource Control Engineer position. It requires a limited type of degree from a limited set of schools, yet engineers at other agencies (such as CalTrans, air resources, CalFire, etc.) allow for engineers that have an EIT and are on the licensing path (which is allowed by the Board of Licensing for engineers). This limits our pool of qualified candidates, when there are licensed civil engineers who cannot be hired because of outdated qualifications. Circling back, the process to even get this looked at is slow because of admin unit turnover and lack of expertise.

This is how things have to change to keep pace with the modern world; CA government needs to embrace the change from a militaristic bureaucracy with "butts in seats" policies and a "because I told you so," leadership style, to a collaborative team environment that allows everyone to do their best work from where they work best.

The biggest issue during my 5 years with the state as someone in IT is seeing computer illiteracy amongst employees. I often hear people say "I'm not a computer person" whenever they come across something they don't understand or have an issue with. I don't think this is an acceptable mentality when over 90% of their job is on the computer! I'm not asking them to troubleshoot everything but I would like to see some effort in at least Googling how to fix minor issues like adjusting a view in Outlook or their display settings.  Here's a few other common things I've encountered.  -Not knowing how to shut down a computer or the difference between shutting down, restarting, sleep, and closing the lid. -What file explorer is and how to navigate network folders. -How to use the search (Windows key) to find stuff. -How to connect to the WIFI and VPN.  That is why I think we need some sort of basic computer literacy exam before people can apply for a job. Maybe add it as a component in CalCareers.  Another big problem I see is paper waste. We spend so much money on printers/faxes, and supplies when most things could just be a PDF. In my dept, I think we spent over a million on a filing system that can be moved electronically.

Creating templates to streamline reports/memos/letters but there is always reluctant to use them by other staff. The most common phrase I heard is "that's not how things are done around here."

There are artificial intelligence (AI) chatbots including Microsoft Copilot Pages, which many state departments have access to. Of course better training is preferred, but having access to an AI-chat bot that can search and give new employees answers about written policies would possibly be a big improvement.

I would say that a lack of functional knowledge is one of the largest issues I see in government work. I would like to see more comprehensive training regarding writing and research skills. I would like to see more comprehensive training regarding professional behavior and correspondence. Most of our trainings are self paced, online trainings, where if there is a quiz at all, it is easily defeated with a google search. I would like to see trainings structured more like college courses where there are not just multiple choice knowledge checks but reviewed responses to open ended questions at several stages in the learning process, and work completed for review, feedback, and revision. I'm guilty of sometimes phoning in a training myself but I also take time to continue my education and I take pride in my work. Not everyone does and then I have to explain to them why or how what they've submitted is incorrect or incomplete. That is not always appreciated and I shouldn't have to train folks that are my superior or at my same level. Also, I would like to see us not use AI very much as it will enable these folks to continue not knowing what they are doing. Plus, the horrific impact to the environment in a state where we should be extra mindful of our environmental impact.

PROBLEM  There is no real-time visual summary of statewide sources of funds (revenues) and uses of funds (money spent on programs and services). The absence of real-time data on revenues and expenses may make it challenging for lawmakers, control agencies and constituents to manage/adjust their budgets based on the latest info.    SOLUTION  Create an online visual tool with real-time data of sources of funds (from CDTFA, FTB, etc.) and uses of funds (to the General Fund, special funds, and locals).   This would enable lawmakers, control agencies and the public to have a better understanding of the current financial state of revenues and expenses overall as well as to individual programs. A real-time (perhaps updated weekly) tool should also enable the State to better forecast revenues, expenses and surplus/shortfalls.

White supremacy is the primary problem that needs to be addressed. This  is an imperfect term that I use here as a catchall for systemic misogyny, racism, and ableism that promotes "rugged individual" myth. There needs to be a major culture shift in our approach to governance and resource management that would allow all people to participate in government. An inclusive government will more effectively serve all Californian's by promoting discussion and rational thinking over our current "follow the strongman" model. This survey feels like a box checking exercise that leadership can use a proof that they asked for input that will not be acted upon. State leadership would benefit from cultural humility training, however, it will take generations to bring about the cultural shift necessary to cause meaningful change. The State of California needs to own its racist actions, past and present. We need to acknowledge that we became the fourth largest economy through genocide, exploitation, and unsustainable resource extraction that continues today, and only benefits a few. Most state employees are ignored, especially scientists who point out that our resource extraction is unsustainable, and racial equity practitioners who point out how our racist policies are hurting oppressed communities. We need to stop being defensive and own our wrongdoing. We cannot solve a problem if we continually deny it's existence.

A problem I'd like to raise is the importance of providing timely and meaningful feedback. Strong managers use the STD 638 to offer the truly earned feedback, where mediocre managers often rank everyone as "M" and provide little, if any,  constructive feedback there or in day-to-day interactions. For those who have been over-achievers all of our lives, to have a mediocre manager provide this is frustrating and off-putting. Encourage managers to work hard on these as this engagement will motivate staff, support professional growth and ensure that high performers feel valued. Less effective managers tend to provide only average or generic reviews, even for excellent employees, without offering guidance on how they can advance. This lack of feedback discourages staff and can hinder development. Additionally, promotions should be based on demonstrated leadership qualities rather than circumstance. A stronger vetting process is needed to ensure promotions go to those who consistently model dedication and performance. HR should also allow and encourage higher rankings for employees who truly give 110%. When staff exceed expectations but their reviews do not accurately reflect their effort, it creates deep frustration and drives talented employees to consider leaving for agencies where their contributions will be recognized. By strengthening both the feedback process and evaluation system, the organization can better retain top talent and truly promote a culture of excellence.

Expedited Purchases: CAL-Cards enable the quickest possible acquisition of goods and services. During a disaster, such as the Mammoth Snow Incident, The January Fires (2025), and the Texas Flooding (EMAC-HR K9 MRP), Traditional purchasing methods like purchase orders or contracts are to slow and can endanger public health, safety, and property.  Acquisition outside of normal business hours: Disaster often occurs at unexpected times, such as nights and weekends. CAL-Cards provide a payment mechanism that functions at all hours when supplies are available. Elimination of red tape: The Emergency Response CAL-Card ERC (Emergency Response CAL-Card) program is specifically designed to cut through bureaucracy for disaster response. It is intended for use after the Governor’s Office has issued a disaster proclamation and when other payment mechanisms are unavailable. Flexibility with vendors: Unlike standard purchasing, the ERC (Emergency Response CAL-Card) has a broad allowance for merchant categories, giving card holders the flexibility to purchase from vendors that are accessible and have the needed supplies and services during emergencies. Recommendation: Authorize and issue CAL-Cards to all Special Operations Assistant Chiefs to: •	Facilitate immediate procurement of mission-critical items during deployments and pre-positions •	Support fiscal accountability and streamline reimbursement processes •	Enhance operational autonomy for A-REPs managing complex field operations

Delays delivery: The additional procurement checkpoints extend timelines, often by several months, discouraging innovation and responsiveness.  Limited accountability: Oversight bodies rarely bear responsibility when projects fail, creating a misalignment between authority and accountability.  Alternative Approach: Shift to agency-led, outcome-based accountability:  Empower departments to own their projects end-to-end, while holding them accountable, to iterate, hold departments accountable, for cost, schedule, and performance.  Replace CDT’s checklist-style oversight with independent milestone reviews (e.g., external auditors or peer agency reviews) tied to measurable deliverables.  Adopt modular, milestone-based procurement (similar to private sector best practices) that enables course correction without massive sunk costs.  Expected Impact: Faster project initiation, lower administrative overhead, clearer accountability, and better use of taxpayer dollars.

Hiring practices often appear inconsistent and inequitable. On one hand, there is a strong emphasis on rewarding current civil service experience, while on the other, external candidates are expected to meet disproportionately high educational and experiential thresholds. For instance, some classifications equate one year of state service to a master’s degree plus three years of professional experience. This raises a critical question: how can a single year of internal service be considered equivalent to such extensive academic and professional preparation? This practice not only undermines the value of formal education and diverse professional backgrounds but also creates systemic barriers for qualified individuals outside the state system—effectively making the process exclusionary.  To improve both efficiency and equity in hiring, California should implement a transparent, competency-based hiring framework. This would involve clearly defining the skills, knowledge, and outcomes expected for each classification and allowing candidates—whether internal or external—to demonstrate their qualifications through a combination of experience, education, and performance-based assessments. Such a model would reduce arbitrary equivalencies, promote fairness, and ensure that the most capable individuals are selected to serve the public, regardless of their entry point into government.

Recruitment and retention of state peace officers is harder than ever over the last 10 years.  Many police agencies have adjusted to the times and now allow officers to wear well groomed beards and display tattoos that are of good taste and not objectively offensive.  However, the California Highway Patrol has not allowed tattoos to be displayed nor male officers to have beards, all for the sake of tradition.  Our modern culture has grown to accept both as acceptable in the workplace, and in fact, makes officers more relatable.  Many communities may be able to relate to an officer who has tattoos, especially younger people.  As the melting pot of the United States, many foreign cultures co-exist in California and universally respect male officers with beards as being elders with serious life, and job experience, particularly when they see gray in the beard.  This makes them more willing to listen and being compliant with an officer.  It's already permitted for religious exemptions, i.e. for Sikh officers.  It should be permitted across the board for all officers.  This may seem like a non-issue to someone not in law enforcement, but other agencies have noticed higher levels of recruiting and retention by allowing tattoos and beards.  It is also a huge morale booster and allows officers to express themselves as individuals and humans, rather than as de-humanized, monotonous, faceless agents of the government. Many Caltrans processes still rely on PDF forms that require downloading, filling out, routing for signatures, and re-entering data into spreadsheets. This creates delays, duplicate work, and access issues — especially when PDFs are hard to use on mobile devices or when handwritten forms are difficult to read.  Instead of routing documents for signatures, we can use interactive online forms to collect structured data and automate approvals. Online forms are faster to set up, reusable, and mobile-friendly. They also ensure accuracy by requiring fields, validating entries, and feeding submissions directly into tabular formats like Excel or SharePoint Lists. This eliminates manual transcription, reduces errors, and cuts down on repetitive administrative work.  The benefits are clear:  - Saves time by reducing steps (no printing, scanning, or configuring signatures)  - Improves efficiency with real-time submission tracking and notifications  - Avoids waste by reducing paper use and redundant tasks  - Supports accessibility by providing legible, mobile-friendly entry options for both office and field staff  This small change could save staff and the general public hours each week and provide cleaner, more usable data for decision-making — aligning with Executive Order N-30-25’s call for operational efficiencies across state government.

Support CA HS Dropouts California currently has the lowest high school graduation rate in the nation—an alarming fact, especially for a state with the fourth largest economy in the world. We can and must do better for our youth and for the many adults who never had a real chance to earn a diploma. In California, certain vulnerable student populations—such as those who have experienced homelessness, incarceration, or time in the foster care system—can graduate with a reduced requirement of 130 credits under AB 216. I propose that this same credit pathway be offered to adults, age 18 and older, who enroll in accredited adult school programs. Many adults who dropped out of high school faced serious obstacles: poverty, family instability, violence in their communities, or disruptions caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. Without a diploma, these individuals are often stuck in low-wage jobs with little opportunity for advancement. A HS diploma opens doors to job training programs, community college, military service, and promotions.  •	The state gains from increased tax revenue as graduates earn higher wages. •	Adult schools benefit from federal funding tied to improved student outcomes. •	Employers gain access to a more skilled and motivated workforce. •	Businesses benefit from the increased purchasing power of newly employed adults. •	Communities see reduced crime rates and greater social stability. Expand the 130-credit diploma option to adults. Its a low cost, high impact solution.

Favoritism and Nepotism in Hiring  Unqualified candidates getting hired or promoted due to personal connections, not merit.  Workplace morale and trust suffer when people perceive that opportunities aren't fairly earned. Erosion of public trust (especially in public or regulatory roles) when the public suspects favoritism in staffing.  We should advocate for more transparent recruitment and selection processes. Push for independent hiring panels, blind application reviews, or standardized interviews. Encourage whistleblower protections for those who report unfair practices.  Circumvention of Minimum Qualifications (MQs)  Some candidates may be circumventing qualifications by enrolling in quick, sometimes low-rigor or unaccredited online graduate programs, just to “check the box.”  This undermines the intent of MQs, which are supposed to ensure a candidate has a certain level of baseline expertise.  It can devalue the profession and create inequities against those who pursued more rigorous paths.  We should push for HR and classification teams to clarify standards: not just “enrollment” but substantial progress or completion from accredited institutions. Consider evaluating equivalencies in a more meaningful way — e.g., experience + coursework, or requiring specific coursework from recognized programs.  Advocate for quality assurance checks on accepted degrees — ensuring they come from regionally accredited institutions, not diploma mills or for-profit degree factories.

The primary problem with working for the State of California is the way staff are treated. Most supervisors receive thorough training on how to issue disciplinary actions, but very little, if any, on how to actually lead, motivate, and support their teams. This results in a culture of enforcement over empowerment, where employees often feel undervalued and micromanaged rather than inspired to perform at their best.  Suggested solutions:   Implement hiring and promotion practices that prioritize: People skills, Proven ability to develop others, and Desire to lead not just manage. Select supervisors based on leadership potential. The work can be learned on the job but emotional intelligence needs to be there before they become a supervisor and have power over peoples careers.  Build accountability for “how” supervisors lead. Tie supervisor performance evaluations and promotions to: Team morale and retention metrics (if there is a high turn-over then something is wrong that shouldn't be ignored), 360-degree feedback from staff (this is one I have implemented upon myself), and Demonstrated leadership behaviors — not just output numbers.  Shift the culture from punitive to supportive. Encourage a workplace philosophy that emphasizes: Employee engagement over enforcement Problem-solving conversations instead of automatic discipline, Psychological safety, where staff feel comfortable speaking up.  Invest in real leadership development not just a book club.

I am concerned about latent return-to-office mandates. I am now considered a statewide leader in that field. My work is best accomplished remotely; the same is true of my colleagues. I cannot speak for others, and many roles are critically accomplished through in-person attendance. However, a blanket return to office mandate is out of touch with the ground reality of the public employees who keep the state running.  A blanket RTO mandate also puts undue pressure on departments and individuals to justify exceptions, particularly when it comes to Reasonable Accommodations; especially those RA's addressing invisible disability. Although I am aware (as an EEO investigator) that bad actors try to manipulate these civil protections, folks who have engaged in good faith interactions with their employers for many years are extremely anxious. Although their limitations have not changed, the expectations surrounding their employment will if RTO moves forward in 2026 (which, despite protective statute, is common via employer-friendly interpretations of RA law and policy).  To me, the solution is obvious: reject blanket RTO so departments can TRULY treat each person & job uniquely. In addition to cost saving, the state will retain employees enthusiastic about their jobs and committed to careers that don't pay like the private sector.

Document/form management is a statewide challenge that could more effectively be coordinated centrally. In the previous century, everything went through the Office of State Publishing, and the State Library had catalogued copies of everything that was published, but now each agency has its own content management system and publishes to the web with no centralized coordination. Retrieval largely depends on private 3rd party services. Index each web address and tag with metatext; leverage librarians' expertise to structure a retrieval system facilitating public access. Track revision dates, ownership, and language translations within the same platform. Use AI document translation with a common lexicon, have a disclaimer and feedback mechanism to prioritize review (e.g. vital docs), ID bad translations, recommend improvements. Also flag items past a certain revise date. At present we have active standard forms owned by agencies that no longer exist and historic documents posted that pop up when searching for current policy. It is not always clear what is current and what is outdated. Systems like WorldCat and GoogleBooks provide models, and there could also be a concierge function for the public to punch in what they need and receive instructions along with any necessary forms and guidelines (perhaps compiled by AI and verified by human staff, moving to spot checks as effectiveness of the tech is demonstrated).
