I know this is the better way because currently we have over a dozen  agencies who don't communicate well and especially don't even have the ability to communicate their locations or talk over the radio, so it' similar to walking through a house in the dark playing 'Marco Polo'. Look at Texas, Tennesee, Colorado, and Arizona. They have a department called "The Department of Public Safety". Highway Patrol, State Detectives, Rangers, Wardens, etc. are all subdivisions of one agency and they communication and collaborate well to better serve there citizen's well-being and tax burden. I am citizen, tax payer, and public servant. Everyday I come to serve the people. I would like to give the people the best service and I know it can be done better this way at a better price.
The purchasing process costs the state tons of money.  We should be able to purchase from the cheapest vendor instead of paying double or triple the cost.

I would like to see my department utilize more up to date ways to share information. My department still has to produce binders with documentation for auditors who have access to our data and they have a SharePoint upload documentation. It would save hours of staff's time and save on supplies and environment. There are times we make 13 4" binders filled with documentation that they have already and can view before coming for the audit.

Each agency has a Mission, Vision, and Goals.  It makes us strive for a purpose.  However, some of these goals need to be cross referenced.  A goal for one agency maybe in direct conflict with another agencies goal.  There are countless examples of this.  Especially when it comes to Environmental.  We (the taxpayers) want a healthy environment, but at what cost?  We (the State Employee) want to do the best we can.  However, typically, low level employees are creating processes that increase regulations, aren't customer friendly, and drive-up cost for everyone.  They are not looking at the consequences of their decisions.  In State government, "everyone has a boss".  Just because we have Directors and other leadership with a goal, doesn't mean they have the authority to dictate regulations.  Many of them make decisions on experience and "the way it's always been done", and that's wrong.  They need to check the big picture.  Sometimes decision makers require unnecessary actions and these cause issues for others.  A great example are Governing boards, such as ARB.  They have good intentions of cleaner air for CA, but at what cost?  Should CA pay $10/gal when the rest of the world is creating global warming.  We are not the problem.  It seems like CA always has to lead.  It would be fine if the taxpayers voted on those regulations, but not when decisions are made by unelected officials.  They have too much power and are just doing what their boss wants them to do.

For our unit we work with foreign vendors to create trade shows or hire consultants in other countries. Our payment of a physical check has presented many issues and in some instances is not a legal payment (i.e., South Africa). Being able to pay via wire transfers is something the Golden State who prides itself in innovation should be able to offer.

We should be able to digitally automate a lot of these checks and notifications and opensource the code that does it. That way we can have a more streamlined process and the public can view, review, and make recommendations.
Absolutely! And housing costs can keep highly qualified employees from applying to positions in areas where they can not afford to live.

Allowing for flexibility in regard to telework. The implementation of a "one-size fits all" policy is inefficient and a waste of money. Telework has proven to be effective and a cost-saver. If it's not working for some departments, then that should be up to the department to make changes. More effective transportation options should also be available. The transit subsidy was a wonderful win, but it would add 3 hours to my daily commute to take public transit to the office. Additionally, collaboration between sister agencies should be encouraged and a focus of the agencies.

As a California resident, I believe our government should reflect the diversity of our state. Representation matters, especially in leadership. We need more diverse women in leadership roles so they can help shape policies and decisions that reflect the needs and aspirations of all communities, including future generations. In addition, we should embrace more innovative ways of working-leveraging technology, rethinking outdated processes, and encouraging creative problem-solving. Innovation, combined with inclusive leadership, can drive more effective, equitable, and forward-thinking public service.

Living in California has always been expensive, but it's just out of reach for many of us now. There is an extreme separation of upper and lower income families with the upper class families paying less in taxes than those who earn far less. Housing is not even close to being affordable for many of us. We also need more reliable public transportation. We also need to take a good look at how we care for our seniors. I have a family member who was recently denied for Cal Fresh even though he only has social security as a steay income and supports himself and 2 family members. They are barely making it yet he couldn't get any help. Perhaps it's time to reevaluate how much income is not keeping up with necessities in California.

Let's create a custom chat bot that resides on several of the most visited CA state websites. Have each state agency, department, council, etc. provide their mission statement and services provided to this chatbot. The LLM/AI could be trained using existing documents provided by each department.  Encourage the public to use this as a resource to find where they need to go to get the help they need. For example, if a citizen is looking for help acquiring health insurance, they would be directed by the AI to Covered California.

Process improvements in order to streamline internal efforts is always a great approach to making the workplace processes and procedures easier to tackle. It is important to get all impacted users input and feedback before adopting the changes.

Telework also allows us to work in safe environments, i.e. in our homes.  In my home I do not need to worry about witnessing racist things written on walls or on notepads (which I have experienced in my office downtown and reported to HR).  In my own home I also will not likely hear inappropriate sexual comments made to women in my office (also something I have experienced in my office downtown and reported to HR).  Working in my own home I also will not have to worry about cockroaches (something I have also experienced in my office downtown).  Working in my own home I also will not have to worry about workplace violence (something I luckily have never had to experience but many others have).  For those people who are not worried about the above (or do not care), they can go work in the office.  I am much more efficient, and less stressed, on my telework days.  Telework works!!

One of the biggest problems with working for the state is employee morale. I have come to understand that the "state" as an institution does not care about me. The beaurocracy is created to avoid risk, not create a good working environment.  One small example of this is coffee and kitchen supplies. I was told that it is against state policy to purchase coffee, filtered water, or even dish soap for employees. This is a little thing, but it makes such a big difference in showing employees that you care about them. I cannot imagine the public would think that employees can't have these basic office supplies purchased for them, when it is so commonplace in every other office I have worked in -- even non-profit organizations!   It is hard to do your best work for an organization that does not care about you. This affects efficiency because it affects employees' productivity.
Yes... less paperwork is always a win. Crazy how small changes can have such huge impact when multiplied over time.

One of the problems we have in our department is that we dont have the ability to purchase simple items such as counter pens for customers to use or clipboards. Its embarrassing for us to tell customers, we dont have pens for them to use or to bring a pen back to me, because its my only one. It also takes us even longer to explain that we dont have tools for them to use than for us to intake them into our department. Also training is so expedited, once we onboard and employee is to be cross-trained right away so our stats look good, but they don't get thorough training to make them efficient. Its all about looking good and having the rights stats, but stats can be manipulated.

We need to get the budget under control.  How do we go from $100 billion surplus to a deficit.  Spending is out of control.  We have spent $20 billion+ on the homeless problem and the homeless issue is worse.  We need to be smart on how we spend our resources!!

The online training is horrible. Placing an ems unit out of service so an employee can complete their cyber security training is unacceptable. Ambulance with paramedic  can’t run calls because of a training program

State agency procurement is unnecessarily complex, involving too many stakeholders in processes that could be significantly streamlined through modern technology. I propose establishing a state marketplace through Amazon's platform where departments can efficiently order goods and services. Within this centralized portal, vendors could submit competitive bids while ensuring compliance with all applicable state mandates and regulations. This system would benefit vendors by allowing them to register once with Amazon and become eligible to sell to all state agencies, eliminating the current burden of navigating separate registration processes across the multitude of agencies that issue requests for bids on goods and services.

1. Use automation tools to improve and increase the scope of testing. 2. Use checklists to ensure quality control. 3. Validate data and practice data migrations prior to any production change. 4. Document all changes made in any production environment. 5. Use version control to make sure only approved changes are deployed.
Smart spending. Communicating with the boots on the ground about their needs and wants instead of blind fully purchasing.

Let's get rid of the low income housing tax credit. It costs twice as much to build using IRC sec. 42 than it costs using market rate building. The exact same goal could be accomplished by 1. Allowing mom and pop landlords to rent to low income folks using either Sec 8 credits or just reduced rent but getting reduced or no property tax, and 2. Having developers build using market based terms not LIHTC, which adds bells and whistles to the units, like granite countertops.

I would address knowledge transfer. People are so concerned with getting promoted quickly, that they don't take the time to learn the job. Since they can't get promoted in their field, they go into supervision. Then you have people who supervise/manage and review the work, who frankly can't do the work themselves.  Then they promote people who aren't qualified to do the work at that level (because they don't understand the work and what it means to get to the next level), and before you know it, you have everyone at the top of the earning ladder and no one who can adequatley do the work. Promotion is important, but they should be merit based, because you demonstrate a higher level of compentancy. And those at lower levels should accept knowlege transfer from people who have put in the time to learn and quit being focused on being at the highest level without having demonstrated that level of competency.
I mean, or even set up offices to function democratically, empowering staff to generate proposals and vote on how to carry out goals instead of assigning an arbitrary supervisor to babysit everyone.
I am working on a project right now and came across RACI - there are different versions of it, but it is a useful tool.  People perform better when they know what is expected of them.

Honestly, giving my team more ownership has been a total game-changer! By really tuning into what each person brings to the table and creating space for creative problem-solving, I've watched my employees transform from just doing their jobs to being real innovation champions. Sure, not every experiment has been a home run, but we've learned so much along the way. The coolest part? My team is now super confident and actually excited about suggesting improvements. They're not just waiting for instructions - they're proactively thinking about how we can do things better. It's like we've shifted from a traditional top-down approach to this dynamic, collaborative environment where everyone feels empowered to speak up and make a real difference. Some of our pilot programs have been incredibly successful, and the energy in the office has completely changed. People are more engaged, more invested, and genuinely passionate about our collective goals. Who wouldn't want a team like that? By trusting them and giving them room to shine, we've created something pretty special.

1. Less training that doesn't apply to my job. The same online training every year is a waste of time. If certain behaviors are not appropriate, then reprimand the wrong doers. It is mentally draining to have to repeatedly do the online trainings when I wouldn't have been doing it without the training, reprimand the wrong doers. 2. There should be an easy way for employees to submit anonymous commits to their supervisors and managers for change. 3. Make it a priority for the State to pay their bills. There is no reason why businesses should go months and months, maybe even longer, without being paid. We as people can't get away without paying our taxes. 4. How about a large pay cut for those responsible for the budget? If we don't do our job we get reprimanded. But if the budget does work out, we get pay cuts. 5. Make the roads better. Stop making traffic lanes for the rich.

One issue I see in my department is duplicative efforts throughout our headquarters operations. I think we could save a lot of money if we looked at our processes, leaned them out, and really focused on streamlining everything. I see a lot of duplicity happening in areas that could be centralized to work more efficiently.

I would have sold my left kidney for a desk manual (or any guidance document, really) when I started with the state. Thank you for being on top of this, I love the idea of having seniors review different sections each iteration. I'm screenshotting this method to use when I next onboard someone ;)
Agreed!!

Software standards.  One example is ServiceNow. This could be used as an IT ticketing system for all state departments.  However, every department selects their own IT ticketing system and then they all pay differing licensing costs. One software where it makes sense, the state could realize cost savings and also continuity across departments, saving in training and add easier coordination.

Let the frontline / lowest level managers decide whether their staff needs to be in office to do their jobs or whether they perform at the same level or better remotely   Managers should know their staff well enough to know what works for their team. What works for one team is not necessarily what works for another   Stop this one size fits all telework mandates and let the managers at the lowest level decide.   Morale would increase, work productivity and dedication would increase and  staff would be happier, saving money on cost of commuting   Happy and satisfied employees mean productive and dedicated employees
Staff should be designated on site to directly impact the support they were designed to do.

When I first arrived, I focused on observing, listening and truly understanding what was happening in our department. Since then, I've been able to implement positive changes that have strengthened our operations. One of the first steps was addressing the organization. I created a RACI Matrix and lists that easily track all that my team has going on. We now have SOPs for each project and staff update them regularly, which ensures consistency and accountability. I also prioritized cleaning up of outdated files, archiving older versions so the most current documents are always easy to find--nothing is deleted, just properly stored. This has made our system streamlined and accessible. I've also modeled simplicity and clarity. I encourage staff to think not only about making their tasks easier for managers, but also about how our work impacts our internal and external partners. That means avoid unnecessary complexity--do not force people to open multiple attachments or links, we summarize key information and provide references as necessary. Our department now feels like a well-run ship because I consistently listen to concerns, take notes, pay close attention to details and operate with a growth mindset that is always focused on continuous quality improvement. Much of my early work felt like cleaning up messes, but through the foundation, it allowed for more strategic planning. I've helped to create a culture of efficiency and accessibility, and respect for everyone's time.

Address root causes for issues in programs, rather than adding more levels of review to catch errors after the fact. Allow staff and supervisors to be accountable for their work, while having autonomy to do it. Look at mistakes as learning opportunities and understand that no process is mistake proof.
I'm brand new to the state. My interests are in employee rights, benefits, training, and upward mobility.

Supervisors working together as a team is crucial.  There should not be 'gate-keeping' of information and we should lift each other up.  Also, confidentiality should be at the forefront in order to protect our employees.

WE are locked into too many limitations, when a decision needs to be made.  There exist certain rules or preset standards that limit the best product from being achieved. The only way to correct this is to abolish these internal standards or rules, and run this organization as a true business, and not as a state expenditure.  Another problem is the limitation or employees not being able to be held accountable at work, since they are protected by the union, and we all know how to correct that.

Using technology to improve services and remove over head with automation. State Agencies are always behind in technology solutions and have anticuated systems. By emprasing technology and find applications that can be used department wide and in several ways, would make agencies manual processes go away and be eaiser to maintain.

An example of work I have done to help improve processes in my department is streamlining our process for medical coding and billing. Supplying clear and concise instructions on how to code and bill appropriately depending on what is being billed. Continuing to provide modern processes to prepare for our transition from paper records to electronic health records.

If backed up by human operators who can review the results, this feels like a good and appropriate use of AI and machine learning. Instead I'm in a department where we're starting to explore the use of ChatGPT to speed up writing and editing original documents, despite LLMs being notoriously bad at these things. I would love to see effort put into exploration of how to use AI where it has documented benefits and usefulness with low margin of error, instead of charging ahead with the shiny Star Trek fantasy applications that the technology isn't actually ready for yet.

There's a need for geospatial intelligence to support State operations. The Federal government has the NGA, but California has no State counterpart. CDT could adopt the role if their staff was increased. Or, a separate agency could be established to acquire, analyze, and provide geospatial intelligence products to State agencies that need them for their operations. Without such a centralized hub, each State agency is on its own to develop a GIS cadre, contract out to receive overhead (satellite) imagery and/or drones. The decentralization ultimately costs the state more money and provides less support, as those with limited budgets might not even request something they need but cannot afford. Establish a California Geospatial Intelligence entity.

As a California resident and taxpayer, I'd like to see less wasteful practices (i.e., purchases, return to office mandates, new building leases, etc.). We are supposed to advocate for the health of the environment and the well-being of the people of California.

As a Workers’ Compensation representative, I’ve focused on improving recovery processes and negotiations to make our work more effective through careful case review, strong negotiations, and consistent communication with attorneys.  I’ve successfully recovered over $5 million in liens for the state. This not only secured significant reimbursement of public funds but also demonstrated how more efficient processes and proactive case handling can lead to better outcomes for both the department and the public.

I believe there should be a universal intranet site with agency-specific and subject-specific subsites.  The main site could include spaces for disseminating information (e.g. statewide policy), posting training and job opportunities, hosting webinars, sharing news on projects and subjects of statewide interest, and collaborating/idea sharing.  This site is a good start but access to a statewide community should be automatic, not opt-in. I also believe the state would benefit greatly from further standardization of web/software design and a collaborative community of engineers. (e.g. having templates for commonly needed software, like procurement, inventory, appointment scheduling, marketing/newsletter, learning management, certification tracking, mobile apps, etc.) Agencies could then customize templates to fit their unique needs. This could make software more accessible and affordable, encourage development of the state IT workforce, reduce reliance on private sector contracts, and create a more universal user experience, reducing the need for training when someone changes agencies. Lastly, I believe data required/used by multiple agencies should centralized to reduce errors/discrepancies and time spent on data entry. A first step would be auditing existing databases to identify what data is being collected by multiple agencies currently.

We use a combination of Microsoft Power Suite and ESRI ArcGIS to remove paper from as many of our workflows as possible. It's a powerful combination as Power Automate can bridge the two environments and allows for reminders, workflows/signature flows, and more. The issue is that the department seems like it would cut access (licenses) to these to save money when these are huge money savers in terms of people's time (hours paid) and costs saved from printing/office supplies. By using drop-downs/choice fields, data is clean and easy to pull into reports in Power BI or ArcGIS Dashboards, etc...
Consolidating files & manuals

Inventory of assets, which should actually be named office equipment: As state employee I receive multiple "Excel Asset Inventory worksheets" from different individuals/departments requesting information about the office equipment I use in my line of work. I suggest streamlining process by centralizing it, creating a dashboard, and give access to interested parties and or departments that need access the data rather than having staff completing multiple worksheets, which creates the risk of inaccurate data and unnecessary processes. Have one dedicated team in charge of managing the disbursement and disposal of office equipment as well as of the maintenance of the database/dashboard for accuracy and accountability.

State agencies and Departments should focus more on recruiting industry subject matter experts in their respective fields of oversight and regulation.  It is all too common for staff to be disinterested or lack knowledge of industries they regulate.
Agree. Onboarding is not complete and unclear. Often left with questions about what to do when you first start.

I will never understand why we are required to purchase from middlemen, just so we can say we support disabled, veteran, and small businesses. All this does is encourage new small businesses to just resell things. That doesn't seem like its adding any value to either the business owner or the state.

One thing I have noticed after working for CDCR for over 25 years is that they put unqualified people in administrative jobs.  An example would be: instead of hiring someone with a business/accounting background to be in charge of "Business Services", CDCR hires someone that worked their way from up from an officer or secretary to run that department.  This happens in the medical department also.

At my department I was asked to help implement data related tools and work to help cut the time to conduct work and be more efficient. We were able to identify crimes and theft much faster and see many crimes that went previously undetected.

Waste Watchers: I loved Gov. Schwarzenegger had a waste watchers type thing. Although the tiny savings of each one person turning off a budling's lights or illegal use of State vehicles (two stories I remember reported there), those individual savings probably didn't pay for the cost to run the waste department, but I think we need something like that. The State Auditor/Whistly blower, I called once and they said, "we are not Big Brother, we have 5,000 calls a year, you have to provide all the evidence to the State Auditor for us to do anything". But as a regular employee I can't access my bosses' records, I can't photocopy the subject state records, nor bring a camera into the place I had another waste/audit complaint. I think in the long run, the state investigating waste, even if not quote fraud, would pay off in long term efficiencies and cost savings. Maybe like a Mello-Roos Tax, if a waste if found the Waste Watcher department gets a cut of the savings to help fund the cost to investigate. Then the Department won't be cut in the next hard budget.

Personally, I do my best to be a responsive team member, and consider myself a teammate of every team.  One of the best things I have seen, though, is the onboarding process at my current department.  In many years of state service, it is the first time I have seen such a thorough (and enjoyable) onboarding process.  A full week of orientation, including all onboarding training (so you can focus on learning your job when you start, not mandatory training), distribution of equipment, assistance with completing HR forms, and presentations by senior management and others.  When it's all over, you are ready to go!

DGS Procurement rules that are same for different organizations.  It should be different for organizations that are buying papers/pens etc vs organizations that need to buy specialized equipment or instruments.   Procurement rules are not effective and efficient and  hinders other departments from doing their job in a timely manner.
Stop spending so much money on outside consultants, work with actual employees. Set up SME's (Subject Matter Experts) and make them actually accessible to employees.

I am a teacher and the process of attendance takes a long time, involves myself, as well as education officers and housing officers. It seems to me that it would be so much more streamlined if we could somehow use the barcode on each IPs ID. As IPs came through a building or left a building, they would scan their ID and their whereabouts would be uploaded directly to SOMS. This would eliminate the need for so many phone calls and such. Seems like a no brainer to me. Of course, their IDs would probably need to be changed to a bracelet or anklet of some kind so as not to be lost or used by a different IP.
The State lacks in succession planning and lacks in providing an environment / process for effective and efficient succession planning.

Providing excellent customer service to customers. Traveling to Norway twice and adding these items in rehab to the institutions for advancing rehabilitation, restorative justice programs, and progressive positive input.

We need digital (mobile-optimized) data intake. The state has SO MANY forms (applications, recertifications, licenses, grants, etc.). Californians should be able to do most of their interaction with the state on their phone (this will make backend data more accurate, too). Their identity should be known at the state, so programs across agencies should share their respective data on the backend so a Californian doesn’t have to enter the same data every time they interact with a new program.

As a state employee that has laterally transferred to different Departments, I've noticed a dramatic difference in the responsibilities and level of expectations for the AGPA classification. In one department, as a seasoned AGPA I was required to have every email reviewed that was being sent to an external source. Another department that I worked for places their AGPA staff in lead roles, facilitating and leading discussions with internal and external stakeholders and the management sit back and watch. These types of inconsistencies can cause people to struggle when they believe they are taking a lateral position but their level of responsibility dramatically increases in their new role, it affects efficiencies when AGPAs with multiple years of experience cannot effectively lateral into similarly positioned AGPA roles.   I believe there needs to be statewide accountability put in place in order to make the level of responsibility across classifications consistent. This cannot simply be done by reviewing duty statements which are broad and do not often reflect the management culture of the office. There should be statewide reviews of internal procedures for varying classifications to ensure that state workers are paid for the same level of responsibility, effort, and commitment.

As a DTSC PM in the office of brownfields I work closely with staff on my project and their supervisors to ensure that deliverables are reviewed in a timely manner and have elevated issues to higher level staff when they arise or when they are foreseen to get ahead of them.  Communication is the key.
I agree 100%.  Elegance and efficiency have left the building.  Managers don't know why things are done and are constantly steadfastly unwilling to change.

I wonder if this relates to the blind hiring they have been piloting that redacts PII from the app materials? It's definitely hard to send a rejection letter if you don't have authorization for the applicant's email address.

As a state employee, the primary problem I would address is to promote employees that really do the work on the daily basis. unfair promotions in those state departments. Those are doing the real work are left aside.

Recruitment - HR needs to work closely with hiring managers to set their process up for success from the start and reduce time-to-hire. Set a timeline, reserve time for application screening and interviews on calendars when the job is posted, not after it closes. Help hiring managers get to yes! Work with them on qualifications to understand the programmatic point of view instead of starting from no. When HR and program work together, it's better for everyone, including candidates!

As a HQ we are too disconnected from the facilities we are serving. We are unable to help them meet policy guidelines because we can't talk about it, record meetings or disseminate trainings or information without taking a year to discuss it first. We are leaving out colleagues out to dry when we are creating the resources for them, but aren't allowed to give the proper trainings on how to use them.

One of the most pressing challenges I see is the restriction on using AI tools in our daily work. This limitation not only slows down innovation but also prevents us from serving our communities with the efficiency, creativity, and responsiveness they deserve.  AI, when used ethically and intentionally, is not a threat—it’s a partner. It can help us streamline repetitive tasks, generate accessible content, analyze data for equity gaps, and even support inclusive language in public communications. These are not luxuries; they are necessities in a modern public service environment. To solve this, I would propose a pilot program that allows the use of AI tools within a secure, policy-guided framework. We could start with low-risk applications—like summarizing meeting notes, drafting outreach materials, or organizing project timelines—and build trust through transparency and training. My vision is not just to adopt technology, but to steward it wisely. With the right guardrails, AI can become a tool for justice, clarity, and care—reflecting the very heart of public service.

there are things most of us NEED to do, as a California Resident.  the DMV springs to mind... It seems that there need to be so, so many more offices to accommodate the number of Californians obligated to utilize the offices.  it's like the grocery stores.  there are so many, because we all need to shop. young families in a neighborhood? need more schools.  it's the same with DMV offices, but i don't really see that in practice.  it's the same few offices since i was a kid, many years ago.  the population is growing (and so is the line at the DMV!)  i would say it's time to do something about that across the state. please.  ☺

One of the biggest challenges the state faces is people feeling they will be chastised for speaking out and the lack of communication between high level management/executives and the people actually doing the work (not managers overseeing work being done, but the actual people at department and agency level doing the work) along with the vendor community seeking to contract with the state. Politicians pushing their objectives and the people making the rules and regulations have either never done the work or haven't done it in so long they do not understand the impact of the policies and procedures, or whether it will make sense to the end user applying the rule. Which also impacts having qualified training (or lack thereof). State training is normally developed and administered by people who are far removed from having done the work. Maybe there should be more in person, role-based training with SME's to assist. Maybe if each department had 1 non-management person (kind of like a SB/DVBE advocate) from each department/agency be a procurement representative to present department issues at a bimonthly forum (like SCAN).   There should procurement meetings for the department/agency representatives where new laws that have been enacted can be reviewed to ensure understanding where they can have a voice to speak about how those are impacting their jobs, etc.

Fragmentation across state/local systems that serve the same people. Programs in health/housing/social services work separately with different rules but serve the same people. They have fragmented data and separate funding/rules. This creates confusion for the consumers, duplication of efforts, and gaps in care especially for the people that most need it.   1. State depts should work together for shared goals and coordinate service instead of running parallel programs that don't connect. And leadership should facilitate that collaboration.  2. Agencies should secure shared data to see full picture of a person's needs and measure outcomes of wellbeing.  3. Give counties/regions flexibility to test local solutions using funding and simplified access to services.  4. Train/rotate staff across departments/agencies so employees can understand how other systems work and work together better to solve problems.

One primary problem I would address is the idea that supervision/management is just the next step in making more money. A supervisory position should be one that helps the team, not one that makes it worse by 1) removing an expert and 2) giving someone a position they're either not ready for or don't really want. Supervisors and managers need better soft, people skills. We need people in those positions who want to lead, connect, and improve their teams. We don't need someone who just didn't have any other way to increase their salary. So, start by fixing the salary system. We need good people in every classification and series, and we need to be able to reward them and their expertise.

Onboarding and succession planning. When joining a new team or department, there have been instances where I was thrown into the job with little training or onboarding materials. I've also noticed that when some folks leave, there is not much planning or knowledge sharing happening. This results in taking many steps backwards on progress previously made. I would also address flexibility in the workplace. Many polices are created for an entire department, but they do not fit all the working conditions of the individual branches and units. I would allow for more flexibility within each branch/unit.

The unnecessary spending. For example, in my line of work, we send people down south for training when the following month we do the same training her in Northern CA. I am all for training but when we are spending $20,000 to send four people down south, I feel like it is unnecessary money, especially when at times these are for new hires. Also, in my department, we have sent the same people year after year to the same training when the employee has come back and said that they didn't learn much more than the year before. Another example is the amount of time wasted on doing the same procedure multiple times, just different ways.

I created step-by-step procedures, including snip pics and highlights, for a few of my duties.  I trained a student assistant and a modified light duty worker to assist me when the work volume was high.  They used the procedures as a guide and found them to be very helpful. As a California state employee focused on educational improvement, I look to streamline cumbersome regulatory processes into collaborative support systems that better serve our local educational agencies. Federal Program Monitoring (FPM)  My most significant contribution has been leading the redesign of our Federal Program Monitoring approach, moving from a compliance-focused audit model to a capacity-building partnership framework. Previously, the FPM process created significant anxiety among LEAs, with extensive document requests and adversarial site visits that consumed enormous staff time on both sides while providing limited educational value. A key component of this transformation involved conducting a comprehensive review of existing FPM requirements to identify regulatory overreach. After systematically analyzing our monitoring protocols, several questionable requirements were brought to the legal team for review. This process resulted in the elimination of multiple requirements that exceeded our statutory authority and created unnecessary burden on districts without corresponding educational benefit.

All boards and bureaus under the Department of Consumer Affairs (DCA) share the same goal: to protect Californian consumers. I often see representatives from various DCA entities at community resource fairs, senior fairs, etc. Outreach teams from different agencies are constantly searching for these events and trying to join them. We pay registration fees, go back and forth with organizers to arrange everything, and travel to different locations.  Why don’t we organize a DCA Consumer Protection Fair ourselves? As many DCA boards and bureaus as possible can join and set up a table/booth. Members of the public can attend and learn about all the resources available to help keep them safe, from how to find a trustworthy accountant to staying safe online, what to do if they were sold a bad car by a dealership, etc. A big issue facing us is that consumers simply don't know that our resources exist until we actively seek them out and inform them.  An Annual Consumer Protection Fair would be a great event for the public and help bring together the work that the Department of Consumer Affairs does in an efficient and targeted way. We could host it as part of National Consumer Protection Week (March 1-7, 2026).

in our present fiscal crisis, a consolidation of governmental agencies should occur to transfer expenditures to front line positions directly impacting and/or benefiting Californians. Consolidating departments and headquarters with similar, associated, or adjacent roles and/or responsibilities will consolidate headquarters locations and all associated Headquarters personnel positions. It will streamline operations to ensure the maximum number of fiscal resources are spent where it makes the most impact on Californians or on State Employees.    Supportive administrative positions should be carefully examined to see if an entry level administrative telework position could do the same work.  Offering those employees to reside in areas of the state with lower costs of living and eliminating their commute time and commute related expenses.  This would make the positions attractive to more prospective qualified employees and should reduce vacancies and amount of time vacancies remain unfilled.  Many agencies have duplicate departments or divisions and the agencies may operate in similar or adjacent fields, consolidation of the executive and managerial leadership, elimination of duplicate faculties, transition of appropriate administrative roles to more entry level telework classifications, will improve effectiveness and efficiency of operations, improve the quantity and quality of services delivered to Californians, and reduce budgetary spending for the state overall.

Government workers are often drawn to state service because of the stability, flexibility, and the mission of public service. At the same time, I do recognize that some employees don’t always engage or collaborate well when working remotely. That lack of participation can create frustration and fuel the push for mandates. But instead of a blanket requirement, I think we should treat remote collaboration and remote work etiquette as part of performance expectations. My experience as a state employee is that many managers—and the culture they shape—need a mindset upgrade. The result is lower morale, weaker teams, and higher turnover. Spending the time to learn how to delegate wisely, listen actively, and lead with vision pays off with stronger, more productive teams. Far too many state resources are wasted replacing staff who leave managers—not jobs.  For inspiration, I recommend Simon Sinek’s leadership talks on YouTube.

As a Californian and a state employee, one primary problem I would address is the gap in consistent internal training and the redundancy that often slows down our processes. To address this, I would advocate for a structured internal training program that includes regular refresher sessions focused on our core duties, our mission, and the ‘why’ behind our work. This would help reinforce a shared sense of purpose and accountability. Another problem I would address is the overlap and redundancy that can occur between agencies or divisions within our department. While each unit has an important role, sometimes our responsibilities intersect in ways that create duplicated efforts, confusion over jurisdiction, or inefficiencies in communication and data sharing. Additionally, I would look at streamlining redundant paperwork and leveraging technology to make our processes more efficient — for example, consolidating overlapping forms into a single digital system or using data-sharing tools between departments. There are major structual issues driving the dysfunction: fragmented authority, a legal inablity to rely on sister agency reviews, and a risk-blind permitting process ( small projects get similar requirements to big projects).   These isuess can't be solved overnight but having a way to measurer the effects and inequities would be a start. There could be a few steps to start:  -Create share reivew systems across agenices so they can work together instead of having separate sources of data on permits. Identify repeated work across agencies.  - Change/update laws to let agencies rely on high quality review done by partner agencies. - Build tiered permittig process that matches level of review to actual risk of the project ( driveway, replacement of infrastructure without increased foot print), versus new industrial center). - Invest in accessible guidance and staff support. Similar to CDFW have scaled permit fees based.

Incorporating 360-degree peer reviews and influence-based leadership models would promote accountability, humility, and a culture of shared success.  Classification System Our current classification structure, designed for factory-style work, doesn’t reflect the dynamic, cross-functional nature of today’s roles. These changes are critical to creating a more agile, inclusive, and responsive public sector.

People often blame CEQA for slowing fuel reduction projects, but the real barriers are limited capacity, planning inefficiencies, and overlapping regulations. Even when CEQA has been waived—such as the 45-day priority projects or the 2025 Secretary’s suspension—we still must comply with all other environmental laws. That often results in more paperwork and delays than if we had simply gone through CEQA. For example, CDFW frequently requires a take permit, which adds 90+ days to a project, making timely fuel reduction even harder.  A more effective solution would be to create a 4(d) rule under the California Endangered Species Act (CESA), modeled after the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service’s approach under the federal ESA. These rules allow targeted exemptions or modifications to take prohibitions for threatened species, so beneficial projects like fuel reduction can move forward without lengthy permitting when impacts are minimal or positive. This is especially critical for California’s fire-adapted species, which often benefit from vegetation treatments.  Currently, CDFW offers Memoranda of Understanding for take, but these are case-by-case, drafted after listing, and far less efficient. A 4(d) rule would instead be established at the time of listing by the Fish and Game Commission, ensuring consistency and streamlining the process. Where federal 4(d) rules already exist, the Commission could adopt them directly, avoiding duplication and aligning state and federal protections.

As a California state employee, I’ve focused on making data processes and services more effective and efficient for both staff and the public. One example is my work on modernizing DMV’s data pipelines and integrations during our transition from legacy mainframe systems to Salesforce. I led efforts to clean, map, and validate large datasets into standardized formats. By automating parts of the validation and transformation process in SQL and Python, I reduced manual review time from days to hours and improved data accuracy before migration.  Another improvement involved documenting and streamlining the change request and deployment workflow for the DVM environment. Previously, approvals and scheduling caused delays due to unclear communication between teams. I restructured the process with clear ownership tracking, ensuring deployment jobs were pre-approved and ready for execution without back-and-forth emails. California's state agencies often have different interpretations of the same policies set by entities like CalHR, the Secretary of State, and DGS. This decentralized approach creates a lack of uniformity in business processes across departments, particularly in areas like Human Resources.  A recent project aimed to identify a "golden image"—a consistent, shared process—for the departments within our agency. However, we discovered that each department follows a different process for the same core functions. This forced us to develop a separate, customized IT system (SaaS) for one department and then hire a consultant to modify the code to fit the next department's unique needs. This constant customization is expensive, with each new system integration costing between $250,000 and $500,000.  By mandating a single, consistent interpretation of state policies, we could achieve significant efficiencies and save millions of dollars. A standardized approach would allow for easier cross-training of staff and eliminate the need for costly, department-specific customizations of IT systems. It would ensure that technology solutions developed for one department are readily usable by others, creating a more cohesive and cost-effective operational model for the state.  Furthermore, it may be beneficial to centralize human resources at the agency level and have one  HR system across the whole agency to save even more money.  This centralized idea can work for other admin areas as well.

Telework should be seen as a strategic system improvement that enhances organizational efficiency and public value, not just an individual workplace accommodation. Implementing statewide telework reduces overhead costs like office space, utilities, and operational expenses—freeing funds for critical public services.  Studies show telework often increases productivity due to fewer distractions and more flexible schedules. This flexibility supports better work-life balance, reducing burnout and turnover—key challenges for the State workforce.  Telework also expands the talent pool by attracting skilled workers regardless of location, which is vital for hard-to-fill positions. It enhances inclusivity by making State jobs accessible to people with disabilities and those in rural or underserved areas.  Additionally, statewide telework adoption demonstrates environmental responsibility by cutting carbon emissions from commuting. Less commuter traffic means public savings through reduced wear on roads and lower maintenance costs. Telework ensures government continuity during emergencies—like natural disasters or health crises—making services more resilient. Overall, telework strengthens institutional performance and public service delivery.

The system of CEAs, or Career Executive Appointments, and appointments to heads of government agencies is perhaps the single largest problem in California government.  The appointment of people with little to no direct experience in the work of an agency results in these CEAs hiring teams of consultants to advise them on what actions to take, which bill at rates of $400-$600/hour ($800,000 to $1.2mm FTE salary).  Then these political appointees hire people that they know who also are not experts in government or the agency's business and use consultants to teach them how to run the business.  Then, anyone with actual knowledge of the agency's business leaves because they're not valued and they see the waste all around them.  They know that they would make more money as a consultant instead or have less frustration working for an ignorant boss and being a punching bag for the general public who don't value the work of government either.   Many state employees are just contract managers and have little or no private sector experience.  The state needs to be serious about paying people what they are worth so they can attract real experts to run departments and to eliminate the system of appointments that destroys expertise.  Politicians are unwilling to pay for the true worth of a worker that knows what they're doing and instead they pay multiples of a true, market-rate salary to consultants and appointees that produce no actual work.  Furloughs also kill retention efforts.
